184
185// C++ utilities.
186
187// New behaves like |new| but uses |OPENSSL_malloc| for memory allocation. It
188// returns nullptr on allocation error. It only implements single-object
189// allocation and not new T[n].
190//
191// Note: unlike |new|, this does not support non-public constructors.
192template <typename T, typename... Args>
193T *New(Args &&... args) {
194 void *t = OPENSSL_malloc(sizeof(T));
195 if (t == nullptr) {
196 OPENSSL_PUT_ERROR(SSL, ERR_R_MALLOC_FAILURE);
197 return nullptr;
198 }
199 return new (t) T(std::forward<Args>(args)...);
200}
201
202// Delete behaves like |delete| but uses |OPENSSL_free| to release memory.
203//
204// Note: unlike |delete| this does not support non-public destructors.
205template <typename T>
206void Delete(T *t) {
207 if (t != nullptr) {
208 t->~T();
209 OPENSSL_free(t);
210 }
211}
212
213// All types with kAllowUniquePtr set may be used with UniquePtr. Other types
214// may be C structs which require a |BORINGSSL_MAKE_DELETER| registration.
215namespace internal {
216template <typename T>
217struct DeleterImpl<T, typename std::enable_if<T::kAllowUniquePtr>::type> {
218 static void Free(T *t) { Delete(t); }
219};
220} // namespace internal
221
222// MakeUnique behaves like |std::make_unique| but returns nullptr on allocation
223// error.
224template <typename T, typename... Args>
225UniquePtr<T> MakeUnique(Args &&... args) {
226 return UniquePtr<T>(New<T>(std::forward<Args>(args)...));
227}
228
229#if defined(BORINGSSL_ALLOW_CXX_RUNTIME)
230#define HAS_VIRTUAL_DESTRUCTOR
231#define PURE_VIRTUAL = 0
232#else
233// HAS_VIRTUAL_DESTRUCTOR should be declared in any base class which defines a
234// virtual destructor. This avoids a dependency on |_ZdlPv| and prevents the
235// class from being used with |delete|.
236#define HAS_VIRTUAL_DESTRUCTOR \
237 void operator delete(void *) { abort(); }
238
239// PURE_VIRTUAL should be used instead of = 0 when defining pure-virtual
240// functions. This avoids a dependency on |__cxa_pure_virtual| but loses
241// compile-time checking.
242#define PURE_VIRTUAL \
243 { abort(); }
244#endif
245
246// CONSTEXPR_ARRAY works around a VS 2015 bug where ranged for loops don't work
247// on constexpr arrays.
248#if defined(_MSC_VER) && !defined(__clang__) && _MSC_VER < 1910
249#define CONSTEXPR_ARRAY const
250#else
251#define CONSTEXPR_ARRAY constexpr
252#endif
253
254// Array<T> is an owning array of elements of |T|.
255template <typename T>
256class Array {
257 public:
258 // Array's default constructor creates an empty array.
259 Array() {}
260 Array(const Array &) = delete;
261 Array(Array &&other) { *this = std::move(other); }
262
263 ~Array() { Reset(); }
264
265 Array &operator=(const Array &) = delete;
266 Array &operator=(Array &&other) {
267 Reset();
268 other.Release(&data_, &size_);
269 return *this;
270 }
271
272 const T *data() const { return data_; }
273 T *data() { return data_; }
274 size_t size() const { return size_; }
275 bool empty() const { return size_ == 0; }
276
277 const T &operator[](size_t i) const { return data_[i]; }
278 T &operator[](size_t i) { return data_[i]; }
279
280 T *begin() { return data_; }
281 const T *cbegin() const { return data_; }
282 T *end() { return data_ + size_; }
283 const T *cend() const { return data_ + size_; }
284
285 void Reset() { Reset(nullptr, 0); }
286
287 // Reset releases the current contents of the array and takes ownership of the
288 // raw pointer supplied by the caller.
289 void Reset(T *new_data, size_t new_size) {
290 for (size_t i = 0; i < size_; i++) {
291 data_[i].~T();
292 }
293 OPENSSL_free(data_);
294 data_ = new_data;
295 size_ = new_size;
296 }
297
298 // Release releases ownership of the array to a raw pointer supplied by the
299 // caller.
300 void Release(T **out, size_t *out_size) {
301 *out = data_;
302 *out_size = size_;
303 data_ = nullptr;
304 size_ = 0;
305 }
306
307 // Init replaces the array with a newly-allocated array of |new_size|
308 // default-constructed copies of |T|. It returns true on success and false on
309 // error.
310 //
311 // Note that if |T| is a primitive type like |uint8_t|, it is uninitialized.
312 bool Init(size_t new_size) {
313 Reset();
314 if (new_size == 0) {
315 return true;
316 }
317
318 if (new_size > std::numeric_limits<size_t>::max() / sizeof(T)) {
319 OPENSSL_PUT_ERROR(SSL, ERR_R_OVERFLOW);
320 return false;
321 }
322 data_ = reinterpret_cast<T *>(OPENSSL_malloc(new_size * sizeof(T)));
323 if (data_ == nullptr) {
324 OPENSSL_PUT_ERROR(SSL, ERR_R_MALLOC_FAILURE);
325 return false;
326 }
327 size_ = new_size;
328 for (size_t i = 0; i < size_; i++) {
329 new (&data_[i]) T;
330 }
331 return true;
332 }
333
334 // CopyFrom replaces the array with a newly-allocated copy of |in|. It returns
335 // true on success and false on error.
336 bool CopyFrom(Span<const T> in) {
337 if (!Init(in.size())) {
338 return false;
339 }
340 OPENSSL_memcpy(data_, in.data(), sizeof(T) * in.size());
341 return true;
342 }
343
344 // Shrink shrinks the stored size of the array to |new_size|. It crashes if
345 // the new size is larger. Note this does not shrink the allocation itself.
346 void Shrink(size_t new_size) {
347 if (new_size > size_) {
348 abort();
349 }
350 for (size_t i = new_size; i < size_; i++) {
351 data_[i].~T();
352 }
353 size_ = new_size;
354 }
355
356 private:
357 T *data_ = nullptr;
358 size_t size_ = 0;
359};
360
361// GrowableArray<T> is an array that owns elements of |T|, backed by an
362// Array<T>. When necessary, pushing will automatically trigger a resize.
363//
364// Note, for simplicity, this class currently differs from |std::vector| in that
365// |T| must be efficiently default-constructible. Allocated elements beyond the
366// end of the array are constructed and destructed.
367template <typename T>
368class GrowableArray {
369 public:
370 GrowableArray() = default;
371 GrowableArray(const GrowableArray &) = delete;
372 GrowableArray(GrowableArray &&other) { *this = std::move(other); }
373 ~GrowableArray() {}
374
375 GrowableArray &operator=(const GrowableArray &) = delete;
376 GrowableArray &operator=(GrowableArray &&other) {
377 size_ = other.size_;
378 other.size_ = 0;
379 array_ = std::move(other.array_);
380 return *this;
381 }
382
383 const T *data() const { return array_.data(); }
384 T *data() { return array_.data(); }
385 size_t size() const { return size_; }
386 bool empty() const { return size_ == 0; }
387
388 const T &operator[](size_t i) const { return array_[i]; }
389 T &operator[](size_t i) { return array_[i]; }
390
391 T *begin() { return array_.data(); }
392 const T *cbegin() const { return array_.data(); }
393 T *end() { return array_.data() + size_; }
394 const T *cend() const { return array_.data() + size_; }
395
396 void clear() {
397 size_ = 0;
398 array_.Reset();
399 }
400
401 // Push adds |elem| at the end of the internal array, growing if necessary. It
402 // returns false when allocation fails.
403 bool Push(T elem) {
404 if (!MaybeGrow()) {
405 return false;
406 }
407 array_[size_] = std::move(elem);
408 size_++;
409 return true;
410 }
411
412 // CopyFrom replaces the contents of the array with a copy of |in|. It returns
413 // true on success and false on allocation error.
414 bool CopyFrom(Span<const T> in) {
415 if (!array_.CopyFrom(in)) {
416 return false;
417 }
418 size_ = in.size();
419 return true;
420 }
421
422 private:
423 // If there is no room for one more element, creates a new backing array with
424 // double the size of the old one and copies elements over.
425 bool MaybeGrow() {
426 if (array_.size() == 0) {
427 return array_.Init(kDefaultSize);
428 }
429 // No need to grow if we have room for one more T.
430 if (size_ < array_.size()) {
431 return true;
432 }
433 // Double the array's size if it's safe to do so.
434 if (array_.size() > std::numeric_limits<size_t>::max() / 2) {
435 OPENSSL_PUT_ERROR(SSL, ERR_R_OVERFLOW);
436 return false;
437 }
438 Array<T> new_array;
439 if (!new_array.Init(array_.size() * 2)) {
440 return false;
441 }
442 for (size_t i = 0; i < array_.size(); i++) {
443 new_array[i] = std::move(array_[i]);
444 }
445 array_ = std::move(new_array);
446
447 return true;
448 }
449
450 // |size_| is the number of elements stored in this GrowableArray.
451 size_t size_ = 0;
452 // |array_| is the backing array. Note that |array_.size()| is this
453 // GrowableArray's current capacity and that |size_ <= array_.size()|.
454 Array<T> array_;
455 // |kDefaultSize| is the default initial size of the backing array.
456 static constexpr size_t kDefaultSize = 16;
457};
458
459// CBBFinishArray behaves like |CBB_finish| but stores the result in an Array.
460OPENSSL_EXPORT bool CBBFinishArray(CBB *cbb, Array<uint8_t> *out);
461
462
463// Protocol versions.
464//
465// Due to DTLS's historical wire version differences, we maintain two notions of
466// version.
467//
468// The "version" or "wire version" is the actual 16-bit value that appears on
469// the wire. It uniquely identifies a version and is also used at API
470// boundaries. The set of supported versions differs between TLS and DTLS. Wire
471// versions are opaque values and may not be compared numerically.
472//
473// The "protocol version" identifies the high-level handshake variant being
474// used. DTLS versions map to the corresponding TLS versions. Protocol versions
475// are sequential and may be compared numerically.
476
477// ssl_protocol_version_from_wire sets |*out| to the protocol version
478// corresponding to wire version |version| and returns true. If |version| is not
479// a valid TLS or DTLS version, it returns false.
480//
481// Note this simultaneously handles both DTLS and TLS. Use one of the
482// higher-level functions below for most operations.
483bool ssl_protocol_version_from_wire(uint16_t *out, uint16_t version);
484
485// ssl_get_version_range sets |*out_min_version| and |*out_max_version| to the
486// minimum and maximum enabled protocol versions, respectively.
487bool ssl_get_version_range(const SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs, uint16_t *out_min_version,
488 uint16_t *out_max_version);
489
490// ssl_supports_version returns whether |hs| supports |version|.
491bool ssl_supports_version(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs, uint16_t version);
492
493// ssl_method_supports_version returns whether |method| supports |version|.
494bool ssl_method_supports_version(const SSL_PROTOCOL_METHOD *method,
495 uint16_t version);
496
497// ssl_add_supported_versions writes the supported versions of |hs| to |cbb|, in
498// decreasing preference order.
499bool ssl_add_supported_versions(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs, CBB *cbb);
500
501// ssl_negotiate_version negotiates a common version based on |hs|'s preferences
502// and the peer preference list in |peer_versions|. On success, it returns true
503// and sets |*out_version| to the selected version. Otherwise, it returns false
504// and sets |*out_alert| to an alert to send.
505bool ssl_negotiate_version(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs, uint8_t *out_alert,
506 uint16_t *out_version, const CBS *peer_versions);
507
508// ssl_protocol_version returns |ssl|'s protocol version. It is an error to
509// call this function before the version is determined.
510uint16_t ssl_protocol_version(const SSL *ssl);
511
512// Cipher suites.
513
514BSSL_NAMESPACE_END
515
516struct ssl_cipher_st {
517 // name is the OpenSSL name for the cipher.
518 const char *name;
519 // standard_name is the IETF name for the cipher.
520 const char *standard_name;
521 // id is the cipher suite value bitwise OR-d with 0x03000000.
522 uint32_t id;
523
524 // algorithm_* determine the cipher suite. See constants below for the values.
525 uint32_t algorithm_mkey;
526 uint32_t algorithm_auth;
527 uint32_t algorithm_enc;
528 uint32_t algorithm_mac;
529 uint32_t algorithm_prf;
530};
531
532BSSL_NAMESPACE_BEGIN
533
534// Bits for |algorithm_mkey| (key exchange algorithm).
535#define SSL_kRSA 0x00000001u
536#define SSL_kECDHE 0x00000002u
537// SSL_kPSK is only set for plain PSK, not ECDHE_PSK.
538#define SSL_kPSK 0x00000004u
539#define SSL_kGENERIC 0x00000008u
540
541// Bits for |algorithm_auth| (server authentication).
542#define SSL_aRSA 0x00000001u
543#define SSL_aECDSA 0x00000002u
544// SSL_aPSK is set for both PSK and ECDHE_PSK.
545#define SSL_aPSK 0x00000004u
546#define SSL_aGENERIC 0x00000008u
547
548#define SSL_aCERT (SSL_aRSA | SSL_aECDSA)
549
550// Bits for |algorithm_enc| (symmetric encryption).
551#define SSL_3DES 0x00000001u
552#define SSL_AES128 0x00000002u
553#define SSL_AES256 0x00000004u
554#define SSL_AES128GCM 0x00000008u
555#define SSL_AES256GCM 0x00000010u
556#define SSL_eNULL 0x00000020u
557#define SSL_CHACHA20POLY1305 0x00000040u
558
559#define SSL_AES (SSL_AES128 | SSL_AES256 | SSL_AES128GCM | SSL_AES256GCM)
560
561// Bits for |algorithm_mac| (symmetric authentication).
562#define SSL_SHA1 0x00000001u
563// SSL_AEAD is set for all AEADs.
564#define SSL_AEAD 0x00000002u
565
566// Bits for |algorithm_prf| (handshake digest).
567#define SSL_HANDSHAKE_MAC_DEFAULT 0x1
568#define SSL_HANDSHAKE_MAC_SHA256 0x2
569#define SSL_HANDSHAKE_MAC_SHA384 0x4
570
571// SSL_MAX_MD_SIZE is size of the largest hash function used in TLS, SHA-384.
572#define SSL_MAX_MD_SIZE 48
573
574// An SSLCipherPreferenceList contains a list of SSL_CIPHERs with equal-
575// preference groups. For TLS clients, the groups are moot because the server
576// picks the cipher and groups cannot be expressed on the wire. However, for
577// servers, the equal-preference groups allow the client's preferences to be
578// partially respected. (This only has an effect with
579// SSL_OP_CIPHER_SERVER_PREFERENCE).
580//
581// The equal-preference groups are expressed by grouping SSL_CIPHERs together.
582// All elements of a group have the same priority: no ordering is expressed
583// within a group.
584//
585// The values in |ciphers| are in one-to-one correspondence with
586// |in_group_flags|. (That is, sk_SSL_CIPHER_num(ciphers) is the number of
587// bytes in |in_group_flags|.) The bytes in |in_group_flags| are either 1, to
588// indicate that the corresponding SSL_CIPHER is not the last element of a
589// group, or 0 to indicate that it is.
590//
591// For example, if |in_group_flags| contains all zeros then that indicates a
592// traditional, fully-ordered preference. Every SSL_CIPHER is the last element
593// of the group (i.e. they are all in a one-element group).
594//
595// For a more complex example, consider:
596// ciphers: A B C D E F
597// in_group_flags: 1 1 0 0 1 0
598//
599// That would express the following, order:
600//
601// A E
602// B -> D -> F
603// C
604struct SSLCipherPreferenceList {
605 static constexpr bool kAllowUniquePtr = true;
606
607 SSLCipherPreferenceList() = default;
608 ~SSLCipherPreferenceList();
609
610 bool Init(UniquePtr<STACK_OF(SSL_CIPHER)> ciphers,
611 Span<const bool> in_group_flags);
612 bool Init(const SSLCipherPreferenceList &);
613
614 void Remove(const SSL_CIPHER *cipher);
615
616 UniquePtr<STACK_OF(SSL_CIPHER)> ciphers;
617 bool *in_group_flags = nullptr;
618};
619
620// AllCiphers returns an array of all supported ciphers, sorted by id.
621Span<const SSL_CIPHER> AllCiphers();
622
623// ssl_cipher_get_evp_aead sets |*out_aead| to point to the correct EVP_AEAD
624// object for |cipher| protocol version |version|. It sets |*out_mac_secret_len|
625// and |*out_fixed_iv_len| to the MAC key length and fixed IV length,
626// respectively. The MAC key length is zero except for legacy block and stream
627// ciphers. It returns true on success and false on error.
628bool ssl_cipher_get_evp_aead(const EVP_AEAD **out_aead,
629 size_t *out_mac_secret_len,
630 size_t *out_fixed_iv_len, const SSL_CIPHER *cipher,
631 uint16_t version, bool is_dtls);
632
633// ssl_get_handshake_digest returns the |EVP_MD| corresponding to |version| and
634// |cipher|.
635const EVP_MD *ssl_get_handshake_digest(uint16_t version,
636 const SSL_CIPHER *cipher);
637
638// ssl_create_cipher_list evaluates |rule_str|. It sets |*out_cipher_list| to a
639// newly-allocated |SSLCipherPreferenceList| containing the result. It returns
640// true on success and false on failure. If |strict| is true, nonsense will be
641// rejected. If false, nonsense will be silently ignored. An empty result is
642// considered an error regardless of |strict|.
643bool ssl_create_cipher_list(UniquePtr<SSLCipherPreferenceList> *out_cipher_list,
644 const char *rule_str, bool strict);
645
646// ssl_cipher_auth_mask_for_key returns the mask of cipher |algorithm_auth|
647// values suitable for use with |key| in TLS 1.2 and below.
648uint32_t ssl_cipher_auth_mask_for_key(const EVP_PKEY *key);
649
650// ssl_cipher_uses_certificate_auth returns whether |cipher| authenticates the
651// server and, optionally, the client with a certificate.
652bool ssl_cipher_uses_certificate_auth(const SSL_CIPHER *cipher);
653
654// ssl_cipher_requires_server_key_exchange returns whether |cipher| requires a
655// ServerKeyExchange message.
656//
657// This function may return false while still allowing |cipher| an optional
658// ServerKeyExchange. This is the case for plain PSK ciphers.
659bool ssl_cipher_requires_server_key_exchange(const SSL_CIPHER *cipher);
660
661// ssl_cipher_get_record_split_len, for TLS 1.0 CBC mode ciphers, returns the
662// length of an encrypted 1-byte record, for use in record-splitting. Otherwise
663// it returns zero.
664size_t ssl_cipher_get_record_split_len(const SSL_CIPHER *cipher);
665
666// ssl_choose_tls13_cipher returns an |SSL_CIPHER| corresponding with the best
667// available from |cipher_suites| compatible with |version| and |group_id|. It
668// returns NULL if there isn't a compatible cipher.
669const SSL_CIPHER *ssl_choose_tls13_cipher(CBS cipher_suites, uint16_t version,
670 uint16_t group_id);
671
672
673// Transcript layer.
674
675// SSLTranscript maintains the handshake transcript as a combination of a
676// buffer and running hash.
677class SSLTranscript {
678 public:
679 SSLTranscript();
680 ~SSLTranscript();
681
682 // Init initializes the handshake transcript. If called on an existing
683 // transcript, it resets the transcript and hash. It returns true on success
684 // and false on failure.
685 bool Init();
686
687 // InitHash initializes the handshake hash based on the PRF and contents of
688 // the handshake transcript. Subsequent calls to |Update| will update the
689 // rolling hash. It returns one on success and zero on failure. It is an error
690 // to call this function after the handshake buffer is released.
691 bool InitHash(uint16_t version, const SSL_CIPHER *cipher);
692
693 // UpdateForHelloRetryRequest resets the rolling hash with the
694 // HelloRetryRequest construction. It returns true on success and false on
695 // failure. It is an error to call this function before the handshake buffer
696 // is released.
697 bool UpdateForHelloRetryRequest();
698
699 // CopyToHashContext initializes |ctx| with |digest| and the data thus far in
700 // the transcript. It returns true on success and false on failure. If the
701 // handshake buffer is still present, |digest| may be any supported digest.
702 // Otherwise, |digest| must match the transcript hash.
703 bool CopyToHashContext(EVP_MD_CTX *ctx, const EVP_MD *digest);
704
705 Span<const uint8_t> buffer() {
706 return MakeConstSpan(reinterpret_cast<const uint8_t *>(buffer_->data),
707 buffer_->length);
708 }
709
710 // FreeBuffer releases the handshake buffer. Subsequent calls to
711 // |Update| will not update the handshake buffer.
712 void FreeBuffer();
713
714 // DigestLen returns the length of the PRF hash.
715 size_t DigestLen() const;
716
717 // Digest returns the PRF hash. For TLS 1.1 and below, this is
718 // |EVP_md5_sha1|.
719 const EVP_MD *Digest() const;
720
721 // Update adds |in| to the handshake buffer and handshake hash, whichever is
722 // enabled. It returns true on success and false on failure.
723 bool Update(Span<const uint8_t> in);
724
725 // GetHash writes the handshake hash to |out| which must have room for at
726 // least |DigestLen| bytes. On success, it returns true and sets |*out_len| to
727 // the number of bytes written. Otherwise, it returns false.
728 bool GetHash(uint8_t *out, size_t *out_len);
729
730 // GetFinishedMAC computes the MAC for the Finished message into the bytes
731 // pointed by |out| and writes the number of bytes to |*out_len|. |out| must
732 // have room for |EVP_MAX_MD_SIZE| bytes. It returns true on success and false
733 // on failure.
734 bool GetFinishedMAC(uint8_t *out, size_t *out_len, const SSL_SESSION *session,
735 bool from_server);
736
737 private:
738 // buffer_, if non-null, contains the handshake transcript.
739 UniquePtr<BUF_MEM> buffer_;
740 // hash, if initialized with an |EVP_MD|, maintains the handshake hash.
741 ScopedEVP_MD_CTX hash_;
742};
743
744// tls1_prf computes the PRF function for |ssl|. It fills |out|, using |secret|
745// as the secret and |label| as the label. |seed1| and |seed2| are concatenated
746// to form the seed parameter. It returns true on success and false on failure.
747bool tls1_prf(const EVP_MD *digest, Span<uint8_t> out,
748 Span<const uint8_t> secret, Span<const char> label,
749 Span<const uint8_t> seed1, Span<const uint8_t> seed2);
750
751
752// Encryption layer.
753
754// SSLAEADContext contains information about an AEAD that is being used to
755// encrypt an SSL connection.
756class SSLAEADContext {
757 public:
758 SSLAEADContext(uint16_t version, bool is_dtls, const SSL_CIPHER *cipher);
759 ~SSLAEADContext();
760 static constexpr bool kAllowUniquePtr = true;
761
762 SSLAEADContext(const SSLAEADContext &&) = delete;
763 SSLAEADContext &operator=(const SSLAEADContext &&) = delete;
764
765 // CreateNullCipher creates an |SSLAEADContext| for the null cipher.
766 static UniquePtr<SSLAEADContext> CreateNullCipher(bool is_dtls);
767
768 // Create creates an |SSLAEADContext| using the supplied key material. It
769 // returns nullptr on error. Only one of |Open| or |Seal| may be used with the
770 // resulting object, depending on |direction|. |version| is the normalized
771 // protocol version, so DTLS 1.0 is represented as 0x0301, not 0xffef.
772 static UniquePtr<SSLAEADContext> Create(enum evp_aead_direction_t direction,
773 uint16_t version, bool is_dtls,
774 const SSL_CIPHER *cipher,
775 Span<const uint8_t> enc_key,
776 Span<const uint8_t> mac_key,
777 Span<const uint8_t> fixed_iv);
778
779 // CreatePlaceholderForQUIC creates a placeholder |SSLAEADContext| for the
780 // given cipher and version. The resulting object can be queried for various
781 // properties but cannot encrypt or decrypt data.
782 static UniquePtr<SSLAEADContext> CreatePlaceholderForQUIC(
783 uint16_t version, const SSL_CIPHER *cipher);
784
785 // SetVersionIfNullCipher sets the version the SSLAEADContext for the null
786 // cipher, to make version-specific determinations in the record layer prior
787 // to a cipher being selected.
788 void SetVersionIfNullCipher(uint16_t version);
789
790 // ProtocolVersion returns the protocol version associated with this
791 // SSLAEADContext. It can only be called once |version_| has been set to a
792 // valid value.
793 uint16_t ProtocolVersion() const;
794
795 // RecordVersion returns the record version that should be used with this
796 // SSLAEADContext for record construction and crypto.
797 uint16_t RecordVersion() const;
798
799 const SSL_CIPHER *cipher() const { return cipher_; }
800
801 // is_null_cipher returns true if this is the null cipher.
802 bool is_null_cipher() const { return !cipher_; }
803
804 // ExplicitNonceLen returns the length of the explicit nonce.
805 size_t ExplicitNonceLen() const;
806
807 // MaxOverhead returns the maximum overhead of calling |Seal|.
808 size_t MaxOverhead() const;
809
810 // SuffixLen calculates the suffix length written by |SealScatter| and writes
811 // it to |*out_suffix_len|. It returns true on success and false on error.
812 // |in_len| and |extra_in_len| should equal the argument of the same names
813 // passed to |SealScatter|.
814 bool SuffixLen(size_t *out_suffix_len, size_t in_len,
815 size_t extra_in_len) const;
816
817 // CiphertextLen calculates the total ciphertext length written by
818 // |SealScatter| and writes it to |*out_len|. It returns true on success and
819 // false on error. |in_len| and |extra_in_len| should equal the argument of
820 // the same names passed to |SealScatter|.
821 bool CiphertextLen(size_t *out_len, size_t in_len, size_t extra_in_len) const;
822
823 // Open authenticates and decrypts |in| in-place. On success, it sets |*out|
824 // to the plaintext in |in| and returns true. Otherwise, it returns
825 // false. The output will always be |ExplicitNonceLen| bytes ahead of |in|.
826 bool Open(Span<uint8_t> *out, uint8_t type, uint16_t record_version,
827 const uint8_t seqnum[8], Span<const uint8_t> header,
828 Span<uint8_t> in);
829
830 // Seal encrypts and authenticates |in_len| bytes from |in| and writes the
831 // result to |out|. It returns true on success and false on error.
832 //
833 // If |in| and |out| alias then |out| + |ExplicitNonceLen| must be == |in|.
834 bool Seal(uint8_t *out, size_t *out_len, size_t max_out, uint8_t type,
835 uint16_t record_version, const uint8_t seqnum[8],
836 Span<const uint8_t> header, const uint8_t *in, size_t in_len);
837
838 // SealScatter encrypts and authenticates |in_len| bytes from |in| and splits
839 // the result between |out_prefix|, |out| and |out_suffix|. It returns one on
840 // success and zero on error.
841 //
842 // On successful return, exactly |ExplicitNonceLen| bytes are written to
843 // |out_prefix|, |in_len| bytes to |out|, and |SuffixLen| bytes to
844 // |out_suffix|.
845 //
846 // |extra_in| may point to an additional plaintext buffer. If present,
847 // |extra_in_len| additional bytes are encrypted and authenticated, and the
848 // ciphertext is written to the beginning of |out_suffix|. |SuffixLen| should
849 // be used to size |out_suffix| accordingly.
850 //
851 // If |in| and |out| alias then |out| must be == |in|. Other arguments may not
852 // alias anything.
853 bool SealScatter(uint8_t *out_prefix, uint8_t *out, uint8_t *out_suffix,
854 uint8_t type, uint16_t record_version,
855 const uint8_t seqnum[8], Span<const uint8_t> header,
856 const uint8_t *in, size_t in_len, const uint8_t *extra_in,
857 size_t extra_in_len);
858
859 bool GetIV(const uint8_t **out_iv, size_t *out_iv_len) const;
860
861 private:
862 // GetAdditionalData returns the additional data, writing into |storage| if
863 // necessary.
864 Span<const uint8_t> GetAdditionalData(uint8_t storage[13], uint8_t type,
865 uint16_t record_version,
866 const uint8_t seqnum[8],
867 size_t plaintext_len,
868 Span<const uint8_t> header);
869
870 const SSL_CIPHER *cipher_;
871 ScopedEVP_AEAD_CTX ctx_;
872 // fixed_nonce_ contains any bytes of the nonce that are fixed for all
873 // records.
874 uint8_t fixed_nonce_[12];
875 uint8_t fixed_nonce_len_ = 0, variable_nonce_len_ = 0;
876 // version_ is the wire version that should be used with this AEAD.
877 uint16_t version_;
878 // is_dtls_ is whether DTLS is being used with this AEAD.
879 bool is_dtls_;
880 // variable_nonce_included_in_record_ is true if the variable nonce
881 // for a record is included as a prefix before the ciphertext.
882 bool variable_nonce_included_in_record_ : 1;
883 // random_variable_nonce_ is true if the variable nonce is
884 // randomly generated, rather than derived from the sequence
885 // number.
886 bool random_variable_nonce_ : 1;
887 // xor_fixed_nonce_ is true if the fixed nonce should be XOR'd into the
888 // variable nonce rather than prepended.
889 bool xor_fixed_nonce_ : 1;
890 // omit_length_in_ad_ is true if the length should be omitted in the
891 // AEAD's ad parameter.
892 bool omit_length_in_ad_ : 1;
893 // ad_is_header_ is true if the AEAD's ad parameter is the record header.
894 bool ad_is_header_ : 1;
895};
896
897
898// DTLS replay bitmap.
899
900// DTLS1_BITMAP maintains a sliding window of 64 sequence numbers to detect
901// replayed packets. It should be initialized by zeroing every field.
902struct DTLS1_BITMAP {
903 // map is a bit mask of the last 64 sequence numbers. Bit
904 // |1<<i| corresponds to |max_seq_num - i|.
905 uint64_t map = 0;
906 // max_seq_num is the largest sequence number seen so far as a 64-bit
907 // integer.
908 uint64_t max_seq_num = 0;
909};
910
911
912// Record layer.
913
914// ssl_record_sequence_update increments the sequence number in |seq|. It
915// returns true on success and false on wraparound.
916bool ssl_record_sequence_update(uint8_t *seq, size_t seq_len);
917
918// ssl_record_prefix_len returns the length of the prefix before the ciphertext
919// of a record for |ssl|.
920//
921// TODO(davidben): Expose this as part of public API once the high-level
922// buffer-free APIs are available.
923size_t ssl_record_prefix_len(const SSL *ssl);
924
925enum ssl_open_record_t {
926 ssl_open_record_success,
927 ssl_open_record_discard,
928 ssl_open_record_partial,
929 ssl_open_record_close_notify,
930 ssl_open_record_error,
931};
932
933// tls_open_record decrypts a record from |in| in-place.
934//
935// If the input did not contain a complete record, it returns
936// |ssl_open_record_partial|. It sets |*out_consumed| to the total number of
937// bytes necessary. It is guaranteed that a successful call to |tls_open_record|
938// will consume at least that many bytes.
939//
940// Otherwise, it sets |*out_consumed| to the number of bytes of input
941// consumed. Note that input may be consumed on all return codes if a record was
942// decrypted.
943//
944// On success, it returns |ssl_open_record_success|. It sets |*out_type| to the
945// record type and |*out| to the record body in |in|. Note that |*out| may be
946// empty.
947//
948// If a record was successfully processed but should be discarded, it returns
949// |ssl_open_record_discard|.
950//
951// If a record was successfully processed but is a close_notify, it returns
952// |ssl_open_record_close_notify|.
953//
954// On failure or fatal alert, it returns |ssl_open_record_error| and sets
955// |*out_alert| to an alert to emit, or zero if no alert should be emitted.
956enum ssl_open_record_t tls_open_record(SSL *ssl, uint8_t *out_type,
957 Span<uint8_t> *out, size_t *out_consumed,
958 uint8_t *out_alert, Span<uint8_t> in);
959
960// dtls_open_record implements |tls_open_record| for DTLS. It only returns
961// |ssl_open_record_partial| if |in| was empty and sets |*out_consumed| to
962// zero. The caller should read one packet and try again.
963enum ssl_open_record_t dtls_open_record(SSL *ssl, uint8_t *out_type,
964 Span<uint8_t> *out,
965 size_t *out_consumed,
966 uint8_t *out_alert, Span<uint8_t> in);
967
968// ssl_seal_align_prefix_len returns the length of the prefix before the start
969// of the bulk of the ciphertext when sealing a record with |ssl|. Callers may
970// use this to align buffers.
971//
972// Note when TLS 1.0 CBC record-splitting is enabled, this includes the one byte
973// record and is the offset into second record's ciphertext. Thus sealing a
974// small record may result in a smaller output than this value.
975//
976// TODO(davidben): Is this alignment valuable? Record-splitting makes this a
977// mess.
978size_t ssl_seal_align_prefix_len(const SSL *ssl);
979
980// tls_seal_record seals a new record of type |type| and body |in| and writes it
981// to |out|. At most |max_out| bytes will be written. It returns true on success
982// and false on error. If enabled, |tls_seal_record| implements TLS 1.0 CBC
983// 1/n-1 record splitting and may write two records concatenated.
984//
985// For a large record, the bulk of the ciphertext will begin
986// |ssl_seal_align_prefix_len| bytes into out. Aligning |out| appropriately may
987// improve performance. It writes at most |in_len| + |SSL_max_seal_overhead|
988// bytes to |out|.
989//
990// |in| and |out| may not alias.
991bool tls_seal_record(SSL *ssl, uint8_t *out, size_t *out_len, size_t max_out,
992 uint8_t type, const uint8_t *in, size_t in_len);
993
994enum dtls1_use_epoch_t {
995 dtls1_use_previous_epoch,
996 dtls1_use_current_epoch,
997};
998
999// dtls_max_seal_overhead returns the maximum overhead, in bytes, of sealing a
1000// record.
1001size_t dtls_max_seal_overhead(const SSL *ssl, enum dtls1_use_epoch_t use_epoch);
1002
1003// dtls_seal_prefix_len returns the number of bytes of prefix to reserve in
1004// front of the plaintext when sealing a record in-place.
1005size_t dtls_seal_prefix_len(const SSL *ssl, enum dtls1_use_epoch_t use_epoch);
1006
1007// dtls_seal_record implements |tls_seal_record| for DTLS. |use_epoch| selects
1008// which epoch's cipher state to use. Unlike |tls_seal_record|, |in| and |out|
1009// may alias but, if they do, |in| must be exactly |dtls_seal_prefix_len| bytes
1010// ahead of |out|.
1011bool dtls_seal_record(SSL *ssl, uint8_t *out, size_t *out_len, size_t max_out,
1012 uint8_t type, const uint8_t *in, size_t in_len,
1013 enum dtls1_use_epoch_t use_epoch);
1014
1015// ssl_process_alert processes |in| as an alert and updates |ssl|'s shutdown
1016// state. It returns one of |ssl_open_record_discard|, |ssl_open_record_error|,
1017// |ssl_open_record_close_notify|, or |ssl_open_record_fatal_alert| as
1018// appropriate.
1019enum ssl_open_record_t ssl_process_alert(SSL *ssl, uint8_t *out_alert,
1020 Span<const uint8_t> in);
1021
1022
1023// Private key operations.
1024
1025// ssl_has_private_key returns whether |hs| has a private key configured.
1026bool ssl_has_private_key(const SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs);
1027
1028// ssl_private_key_* perform the corresponding operation on
1029// |SSL_PRIVATE_KEY_METHOD|. If there is a custom private key configured, they
1030// call the corresponding function or |complete| depending on whether there is a
1031// pending operation. Otherwise, they implement the operation with
1032// |EVP_PKEY|.
1033
1034enum ssl_private_key_result_t ssl_private_key_sign(
1035 SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs, uint8_t *out, size_t *out_len, size_t max_out,
1036 uint16_t sigalg, Span<const uint8_t> in);
1037
1038enum ssl_private_key_result_t ssl_private_key_decrypt(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs,
1039 uint8_t *out,
1040 size_t *out_len,
1041 size_t max_out,
1042 Span<const uint8_t> in);
1043
1044// ssl_private_key_supports_signature_algorithm returns whether |hs|'s private
1045// key supports |sigalg|.
1046bool ssl_private_key_supports_signature_algorithm(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs,
1047 uint16_t sigalg);
1048
1049// ssl_public_key_verify verifies that the |signature| is valid for the public
1050// key |pkey| and input |in|, using the signature algorithm |sigalg|.
1051bool ssl_public_key_verify(SSL *ssl, Span<const uint8_t> signature,
1052 uint16_t sigalg, EVP_PKEY *pkey,
1053 Span<const uint8_t> in);
1054
1055
1056// Key shares.
1057
1058// SSLKeyShare abstracts over Diffie-Hellman-like key exchanges.
1059class SSLKeyShare {
1060 public:
1061 virtual ~SSLKeyShare() {}
1062 static constexpr bool kAllowUniquePtr = true;
1063 HAS_VIRTUAL_DESTRUCTOR
1064
1065 // Create returns a SSLKeyShare instance for use with group |group_id| or
1066 // nullptr on error.
1067 static UniquePtr<SSLKeyShare> Create(uint16_t group_id);
1068
1069 // Create deserializes an SSLKeyShare instance previously serialized by
1070 // |Serialize|.
1071 static UniquePtr<SSLKeyShare> Create(CBS *in);
1072
1073 // Serializes writes the group ID and private key, in a format that can be
1074 // read by |Create|.
1075 bool Serialize(CBB *out);
1076
1077 // GroupID returns the group ID.
1078 virtual uint16_t GroupID() const PURE_VIRTUAL;
1079
1080 // Offer generates a keypair and writes the public value to
1081 // |out_public_key|. It returns true on success and false on error.
1082 virtual bool Offer(CBB *out_public_key) PURE_VIRTUAL;
1083
1084 // Accept performs a key exchange against the |peer_key| generated by |Offer|.
1085 // On success, it returns true, writes the public value to |out_public_key|,
1086 // and sets |*out_secret| to the shared secret. On failure, it returns false
1087 // and sets |*out_alert| to an alert to send to the peer.
1088 //
1089 // The default implementation calls |Offer| and then |Finish|, assuming a key
1090 // exchange protocol where the peers are symmetric.
1091 virtual bool Accept(CBB *out_public_key, Array<uint8_t> *out_secret,
1092 uint8_t *out_alert, Span<const uint8_t> peer_key);
1093
1094 // Finish performs a key exchange against the |peer_key| generated by
1095 // |Accept|. On success, it returns true and sets |*out_secret| to the shared
1096 // secret. On failure, it returns false and sets |*out_alert| to an alert to
1097 // send to the peer.
1098 virtual bool Finish(Array<uint8_t> *out_secret, uint8_t *out_alert,
1099 Span<const uint8_t> peer_key) PURE_VIRTUAL;
1100
1101 // SerializePrivateKey writes the private key to |out|, returning true if
1102 // successful and false otherwise. It should be called after |Offer|.
1103 virtual bool SerializePrivateKey(CBB *out) { return false; }
1104
1105 // DeserializePrivateKey initializes the state of the key exchange from |in|,
1106 // returning true if successful and false otherwise.
1107 virtual bool DeserializePrivateKey(CBS *in) { return false; }
1108};
1109
1110struct NamedGroup {
1111 int nid;
1112 uint16_t group_id;
1113 const char name[8], alias[11];
1114};
1115
1116// NamedGroups returns all supported groups.
1117Span<const NamedGroup> NamedGroups();
1118
1119// ssl_nid_to_group_id looks up the group corresponding to |nid|. On success, it
1120// sets |*out_group_id| to the group ID and returns true. Otherwise, it returns
1121// false.
1122bool ssl_nid_to_group_id(uint16_t *out_group_id, int nid);
1123
1124// ssl_name_to_group_id looks up the group corresponding to the |name| string of
1125// length |len|. On success, it sets |*out_group_id| to the group ID and returns
1126// true. Otherwise, it returns false.
1127bool ssl_name_to_group_id(uint16_t *out_group_id, const char *name, size_t len);
1128
1129
1130// Handshake messages.
1131
1132struct SSLMessage {
1133 bool is_v2_hello;
1134 uint8_t type;
1135 CBS body;
1136 // raw is the entire serialized handshake message, including the TLS or DTLS
1137 // message header.
1138 CBS raw;
1139};
1140
1141// SSL_MAX_HANDSHAKE_FLIGHT is the number of messages, including
1142// ChangeCipherSpec, in the longest handshake flight. Currently this is the
1143// client's second leg in a full handshake when client certificates, NPN, and
1144// Channel ID, are all enabled.
1145#define SSL_MAX_HANDSHAKE_FLIGHT 7
1146
1147extern const uint8_t kHelloRetryRequest[SSL3_RANDOM_SIZE];
1148extern const uint8_t kTLS12DowngradeRandom[8];
1149extern const uint8_t kTLS13DowngradeRandom[8];
1150extern const uint8_t kJDK11DowngradeRandom[8];
1151
1152// ssl_max_handshake_message_len returns the maximum number of bytes permitted
1153// in a handshake message for |ssl|.
1154size_t ssl_max_handshake_message_len(const SSL *ssl);
1155
1156// tls_can_accept_handshake_data returns whether |ssl| is able to accept more
1157// data into handshake buffer.
1158bool tls_can_accept_handshake_data(const SSL *ssl, uint8_t *out_alert);
1159
1160// tls_has_unprocessed_handshake_data returns whether there is buffered
1161// handshake data that has not been consumed by |get_message|.
1162bool tls_has_unprocessed_handshake_data(const SSL *ssl);
1163
1164// tls_append_handshake_data appends |data| to the handshake buffer. It returns
1165// true on success and false on allocation failure.
1166bool tls_append_handshake_data(SSL *ssl, Span<const uint8_t> data);
1167
1168// dtls_has_unprocessed_handshake_data behaves like
1169// |tls_has_unprocessed_handshake_data| for DTLS.
1170bool dtls_has_unprocessed_handshake_data(const SSL *ssl);
1171
1172// tls_flush_pending_hs_data flushes any handshake plaintext data.
1173bool tls_flush_pending_hs_data(SSL *ssl);
1174
1175struct DTLS_OUTGOING_MESSAGE {
1176 DTLS_OUTGOING_MESSAGE() {}
1177 DTLS_OUTGOING_MESSAGE(const DTLS_OUTGOING_MESSAGE &) = delete;
1178 DTLS_OUTGOING_MESSAGE &operator=(const DTLS_OUTGOING_MESSAGE &) = delete;
1179 ~DTLS_OUTGOING_MESSAGE() { Clear(); }
1180
1181 void Clear();
1182
1183 uint8_t *data = nullptr;
1184 uint32_t len = 0;
1185 uint16_t epoch = 0;
1186 bool is_ccs = false;
1187};
1188
1189// dtls_clear_outgoing_messages releases all buffered outgoing messages.
1190void dtls_clear_outgoing_messages(SSL *ssl);
1191
1192
1193// Callbacks.
1194
1195// ssl_do_info_callback calls |ssl|'s info callback, if set.
1196void ssl_do_info_callback(const SSL *ssl, int type, int value);
1197
1198// ssl_do_msg_callback calls |ssl|'s message callback, if set.
1199void ssl_do_msg_callback(const SSL *ssl, int is_write, int content_type,
1200 Span<const uint8_t> in);
1201
1202
1203// Transport buffers.
1204
1205class SSLBuffer {
1206 public:
1207 SSLBuffer() {}
1208 ~SSLBuffer() { Clear(); }
1209
1210 SSLBuffer(const SSLBuffer &) = delete;
1211 SSLBuffer &operator=(const SSLBuffer &) = delete;
1212
1213 uint8_t *data() { return buf_ + offset_; }
1214 size_t size() const { return size_; }
1215 bool empty() const { return size_ == 0; }
1216 size_t cap() const { return cap_; }
1217
1218 Span<uint8_t> span() { return MakeSpan(data(), size()); }
1219
1220 Span<uint8_t> remaining() {
1221 return MakeSpan(data() + size(), cap() - size());
1222 }
1223
1224 // Clear releases the buffer.
1225 void Clear();
1226
1227 // EnsureCap ensures the buffer has capacity at least |new_cap|, aligned such
1228 // that data written after |header_len| is aligned to a
1229 // |SSL3_ALIGN_PAYLOAD|-byte boundary. It returns true on success and false
1230 // on error.
1231 bool EnsureCap(size_t header_len, size_t new_cap);
1232
1233 // DidWrite extends the buffer by |len|. The caller must have filled in to
1234 // this point.
1235 void DidWrite(size_t len);
1236
1237 // Consume consumes |len| bytes from the front of the buffer. The memory
1238 // consumed will remain valid until the next call to |DiscardConsumed| or
1239 // |Clear|.
1240 void Consume(size_t len);
1241
1242 // DiscardConsumed discards the consumed bytes from the buffer. If the buffer
1243 // is now empty, it releases memory used by it.
1244 void DiscardConsumed();
1245
1246 private:
1247 // buf_ is the memory allocated for this buffer.
1248 uint8_t *buf_ = nullptr;
1249 // offset_ is the offset into |buf_| which the buffer contents start at.
1250 uint16_t offset_ = 0;
1251 // size_ is the size of the buffer contents from |buf_| + |offset_|.
1252 uint16_t size_ = 0;
1253 // cap_ is how much memory beyond |buf_| + |offset_| is available.
1254 uint16_t cap_ = 0;
1255 // inline_buf_ is a static buffer for short reads.
1256 uint8_t inline_buf_[SSL3_RT_HEADER_LENGTH];
1257 // buf_allocated_ is true if |buf_| points to allocated data and must be freed
1258 // or false if it points into |inline_buf_|.
1259 bool buf_allocated_ = false;
1260};
1261
1262// ssl_read_buffer_extend_to extends the read buffer to the desired length. For
1263// TLS, it reads to the end of the buffer until the buffer is |len| bytes
1264// long. For DTLS, it reads a new packet and ignores |len|. It returns one on
1265// success, zero on EOF, and a negative number on error.
1266//
1267// It is an error to call |ssl_read_buffer_extend_to| in DTLS when the buffer is
1268// non-empty.
1269int ssl_read_buffer_extend_to(SSL *ssl, size_t len);
1270
1271// ssl_handle_open_record handles the result of passing |ssl->s3->read_buffer|
1272// to a record-processing function. If |ret| is a success or if the caller
1273// should retry, it returns one and sets |*out_retry|. Otherwise, it returns <=
1274// 0.
1275int ssl_handle_open_record(SSL *ssl, bool *out_retry, ssl_open_record_t ret,
1276 size_t consumed, uint8_t alert);
1277
1278// ssl_write_buffer_flush flushes the write buffer to the transport. It returns
1279// one on success and <= 0 on error. For DTLS, whether or not the write
1280// succeeds, the write buffer will be cleared.
1281int ssl_write_buffer_flush(SSL *ssl);
1282
1283
1284// Certificate functions.
1285
1286// ssl_has_certificate returns whether a certificate and private key are
1287// configured.
1288bool ssl_has_certificate(const SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs);
1289
1290// ssl_parse_cert_chain parses a certificate list from |cbs| in the format used
1291// by a TLS Certificate message. On success, it advances |cbs| and returns
1292// true. Otherwise, it returns false and sets |*out_alert| to an alert to send
1293// to the peer.
1294//
1295// If the list is non-empty then |*out_chain| and |*out_pubkey| will be set to
1296// the certificate chain and the leaf certificate's public key
1297// respectively. Otherwise, both will be set to nullptr.
1298//
1299// If the list is non-empty and |out_leaf_sha256| is non-NULL, it writes the
1300// SHA-256 hash of the leaf to |out_leaf_sha256|.
1301bool ssl_parse_cert_chain(uint8_t *out_alert,
1302 UniquePtr<STACK_OF(CRYPTO_BUFFER)> *out_chain,
1303 UniquePtr<EVP_PKEY> *out_pubkey,
1304 uint8_t *out_leaf_sha256, CBS *cbs,
1305 CRYPTO_BUFFER_POOL *pool);
1306
1307// ssl_add_cert_chain adds |hs->ssl|'s certificate chain to |cbb| in the format
1308// used by a TLS Certificate message. If there is no certificate chain, it emits
1309// an empty certificate list. It returns true on success and false on error.
1310bool ssl_add_cert_chain(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs, CBB *cbb);
1311
1312enum ssl_key_usage_t {
1313 key_usage_digital_signature = 0,
1314 key_usage_encipherment = 2,
1315};
1316
1317// ssl_cert_check_key_usage parses the DER-encoded, X.509 certificate in |in|
1318// and returns true if doesn't specify a key usage or, if it does, if it
1319// includes |bit|. Otherwise it pushes to the error queue and returns false.
1320bool ssl_cert_check_key_usage(const CBS *in, enum ssl_key_usage_t bit);
1321
1322// ssl_cert_parse_pubkey extracts the public key from the DER-encoded, X.509
1323// certificate in |in|. It returns an allocated |EVP_PKEY| or else returns
1324// nullptr and pushes to the error queue.
1325UniquePtr<EVP_PKEY> ssl_cert_parse_pubkey(const CBS *in);
1326
1327// ssl_parse_client_CA_list parses a CA list from |cbs| in the format used by a
1328// TLS CertificateRequest message. On success, it returns a newly-allocated
1329// |CRYPTO_BUFFER| list and advances |cbs|. Otherwise, it returns nullptr and
1330// sets |*out_alert| to an alert to send to the peer.
1331UniquePtr<STACK_OF(CRYPTO_BUFFER)> ssl_parse_client_CA_list(SSL *ssl,
1332 uint8_t *out_alert,
1333 CBS *cbs);
1334
1335// ssl_has_client_CAs returns there are configured CAs.
1336bool ssl_has_client_CAs(const SSL_CONFIG *cfg);
1337
1338// ssl_add_client_CA_list adds the configured CA list to |cbb| in the format
1339// used by a TLS CertificateRequest message. It returns true on success and
1340// false on error.
1341bool ssl_add_client_CA_list(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs, CBB *cbb);
1342
1343// ssl_check_leaf_certificate returns one if |pkey| and |leaf| are suitable as
1344// a server's leaf certificate for |hs|. Otherwise, it returns zero and pushes
1345// an error on the error queue.
1346bool ssl_check_leaf_certificate(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs, EVP_PKEY *pkey,
1347 const CRYPTO_BUFFER *leaf);
1348
1349// ssl_on_certificate_selected is called once the certificate has been selected.
1350// It finalizes the certificate and initializes |hs->local_pubkey|. It returns
1351// true on success and false on error.
1352bool ssl_on_certificate_selected(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs);
1353
1354
1355// TLS 1.3 key derivation.
1356
1357// tls13_init_key_schedule initializes the handshake hash and key derivation
1358// state, and incorporates the PSK. The cipher suite and PRF hash must have been
1359// selected at this point. It returns true on success and false on error.
1360bool tls13_init_key_schedule(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs, Span<const uint8_t> psk);
1361
1362// tls13_init_early_key_schedule initializes the handshake hash and key
1363// derivation state from the resumption secret and incorporates the PSK to
1364// derive the early secrets. It returns one on success and zero on error.
1365bool tls13_init_early_key_schedule(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs, Span<const uint8_t> psk);
1366
1367// tls13_advance_key_schedule incorporates |in| into the key schedule with
1368// HKDF-Extract. It returns true on success and false on error.
1369bool tls13_advance_key_schedule(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs, Span<const uint8_t> in);
1370
1371// tls13_set_traffic_key sets the read or write traffic keys to
1372// |traffic_secret|. The version and cipher suite are determined from |session|.
1373// It returns true on success and false on error.
1374bool tls13_set_traffic_key(SSL *ssl, enum ssl_encryption_level_t level,
1375 enum evp_aead_direction_t direction,
1376 const SSL_SESSION *session,
1377 Span<const uint8_t> traffic_secret);
1378
1379// tls13_derive_early_secret derives the early traffic secret. It returns true
1380// on success and false on error.
1381bool tls13_derive_early_secret(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs);
1382
1383// tls13_derive_handshake_secrets derives the handshake traffic secret. It
1384// returns true on success and false on error.
1385bool tls13_derive_handshake_secrets(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs);
1386
1387// tls13_rotate_traffic_key derives the next read or write traffic secret. It
1388// returns true on success and false on error.
1389bool tls13_rotate_traffic_key(SSL *ssl, enum evp_aead_direction_t direction);
1390
1391// tls13_derive_application_secrets derives the initial application data traffic
1392// and exporter secrets based on the handshake transcripts and |master_secret|.
1393// It returns true on success and false on error.
1394bool tls13_derive_application_secrets(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs);
1395
1396// tls13_derive_resumption_secret derives the |resumption_secret|.
1397bool tls13_derive_resumption_secret(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs);
1398
1399// tls13_export_keying_material provides an exporter interface to use the
1400// |exporter_secret|.
1401bool tls13_export_keying_material(SSL *ssl, Span<uint8_t> out,
1402 Span<const uint8_t> secret,
1403 Span<const char> label,
1404 Span<const uint8_t> context);
1405
1406// tls13_finished_mac calculates the MAC of the handshake transcript to verify
1407// the integrity of the Finished message, and stores the result in |out| and
1408// length in |out_len|. |is_server| is true if this is for the Server Finished
1409// and false for the Client Finished.
1410bool tls13_finished_mac(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs, uint8_t *out, size_t *out_len,
1411 bool is_server);
1412
1413// tls13_derive_session_psk calculates the PSK for this session based on the
1414// resumption master secret and |nonce|. It returns true on success, and false
1415// on failure.
1416bool tls13_derive_session_psk(SSL_SESSION *session, Span<const uint8_t> nonce);
1417
1418// tls13_write_psk_binder calculates the PSK binder value and replaces the last
1419// bytes of |msg| with the resulting value. It returns true on success, and
1420// false on failure.
1421bool tls13_write_psk_binder(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs, Span<uint8_t> msg);
1422
1423// tls13_verify_psk_binder verifies that the handshake transcript, truncated up
1424// to the binders has a valid signature using the value of |session|'s
1425// resumption secret. It returns true on success, and false on failure.
1426bool tls13_verify_psk_binder(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs, SSL_SESSION *session,
1427 const SSLMessage &msg, CBS *binders);
1428

1430// Encrypted ClientHello.
1431
1432class ECHServerConfig {
1433 public:
1434 static constexpr bool kAllowUniquePtr = true;
1435 ECHServerConfig() : is_retry_config_(false), initialized_(false) {}
1436 ECHServerConfig(const ECHServerConfig &other) = delete;
1437 ~ECHServerConfig() = default;
1438 ECHServerConfig &operator=(ECHServerConfig &&) = delete;
1439
1440 // Init parses |ech_config| as an ECHConfig and saves a copy of |private_key|.
1441 // It returns true on success and false on error. It will also error if
1442 // |private_key| is not a valid X25519 private key or it does not correspond
1443 // to the parsed public key.
1444 bool Init(Span<const uint8_t> ech_config, Span<const uint8_t> private_key,
1445 bool is_retry_config);
1446
1447 // SetupContext sets up |ctx| for a new connection, given the specified
1448 // HPKE ciphersuite and encapsulated KEM key. It returns true on success and
1449 // false on error. This function may only be called on an initialized object.
1450 bool SetupContext(EVP_HPKE_CTX *ctx, uint16_t kdf_id, uint16_t aead_id,
1451 Span<const uint8_t> enc) const;
1452
1453 Span<const uint8_t> ech_config() const {
1454 assert(initialized_);
1455 return ech_config_;
1456 }
1457 bool is_retry_config() const {
1458 assert(initialized_);
1459 return is_retry_config_;
1460 }
1461 uint8_t config_id() const {
1462 assert(initialized_);
1463 return config_id_;
1464 }
1465
1466 private:
1467 Array<uint8_t> ech_config_;
1468 Span<const uint8_t> cipher_suites_;
1469 ScopedEVP_HPKE_KEY key_;
1470
1471 uint8_t config_id_;
1472
1473 bool is_retry_config_ : 1;
1474 bool initialized_ : 1;
1475};
1476
1477// ssl_decode_client_hello_inner recovers the full ClientHelloInner from the
1478// EncodedClientHelloInner |encoded_client_hello_inner| by replacing its
1479// outer_extensions extension with the referenced extensions from the
1480// ClientHelloOuter |client_hello_outer|. If successful, it writes the recovered
1481// ClientHelloInner to |out_client_hello_inner|. It returns true on success and
1482// false on failure.
1483OPENSSL_EXPORT bool ssl_decode_client_hello_inner(
1484 SSL *ssl, uint8_t *out_alert, Array<uint8_t> *out_client_hello_inner,
1485 Span<const uint8_t> encoded_client_hello_inner,
1486 const SSL_CLIENT_HELLO *client_hello_outer);
1487
1488// ssl_client_hello_decrypt attempts to decrypt the given |payload| into
1489// |out_encoded_client_hello_inner|. The decrypted value should be an
1490// EncodedClientHelloInner. It returns false if any fatal errors occur and true
1491// otherwise, regardless of whether the decrypt was successful. It sets
1492// |out_encoded_client_hello_inner| to true if the decryption fails, and false
1493// otherwise.
1494bool ssl_client_hello_decrypt(EVP_HPKE_CTX *hpke_ctx,
1495 Array<uint8_t> *out_encoded_client_hello_inner,
1496 bool *out_is_decrypt_error,
1497 const SSL_CLIENT_HELLO *client_hello_outer,
1498 uint16_t kdf_id, uint16_t aead_id,
1499 uint8_t config_id, Span<const uint8_t> enc,
1500 Span<const uint8_t> payload);
1501
1502// tls13_ech_accept_confirmation computes the server's ECH acceptance signal,
1503// writing it to |out|. It returns true on success, and false on failure.
1504bool tls13_ech_accept_confirmation(
1505 SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs, bssl::Span<uint8_t> out,
1506 bssl::Span<const uint8_t> server_hello_ech_conf);

1508
1509// Delegated credentials.
1510
1511// This structure stores a delegated credential (DC) as defined by
1512// draft-ietf-tls-subcerts-03.
1513struct DC {
1514 static constexpr bool kAllowUniquePtr = true;
1515 ~DC();
1516
1517 // Dup returns a copy of this DC and takes references to |raw| and |pkey|.
1518 UniquePtr<DC> Dup();
1519
1520 // Parse parses the delegated credential stored in |in|. If successful it
1521 // returns the parsed structure, otherwise it returns |nullptr| and sets
1522 // |*out_alert|.
1523 static UniquePtr<DC> Parse(CRYPTO_BUFFER *in, uint8_t *out_alert);
1524
1525 // raw is the delegated credential encoded as specified in draft-ietf-tls-
1526 // subcerts-03.
1527 UniquePtr<CRYPTO_BUFFER> raw;
1528
1529 // expected_cert_verify_algorithm is the signature scheme of the DC public
1530 // key.
1531 uint16_t expected_cert_verify_algorithm = 0;
1532
1533 // pkey is the public key parsed from |public_key|.
1534 UniquePtr<EVP_PKEY> pkey;
1535
1536 private:
1537 friend DC* New<DC>();
1538 DC();
1539};
1540
1541// ssl_signing_with_dc returns true if the peer has indicated support for
1542// delegated credentials and this host has sent a delegated credential in
1543// response. If this is true then we've committed to using the DC in the
1544// handshake.
1545bool ssl_signing_with_dc(const SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs);

1554 ssl_hs_read_message,

1558 ssl_hs_handback,

1560 ssl_hs_channel_id_lookup,
1561 ssl_hs_private_key_operation,
1562 ssl_hs_pending_session,
1563 ssl_hs_pending_ticket,
1564 ssl_hs_early_return,
1565 ssl_hs_early_data_rejected,
1566 ssl_hs_read_end_of_early_data,
1567 ssl_hs_read_change_cipher_spec,
1568 ssl_hs_certificate_verify,
1569 ssl_hs_hints_ready,
1570};

1627// handback_t lists the points in the state machine where a handback can occur.
1628// These are the different points at which key material is no longer needed.
1629enum handback_t {
1630 handback_after_session_resumption = 0,
1631 handback_after_ecdhe = 1,
1632 handback_after_handshake = 2,
1633 handback_tls13 = 3,
1634 handback_max_value = handback_tls13,
1635};

1637// SSL_HANDSHAKE_HINTS contains handshake hints for a connection. See
1638// |SSL_request_handshake_hints| and related functions.
1639struct SSL_HANDSHAKE_HINTS {
1640 static constexpr bool kAllowUniquePtr = true;
1641
1642 Array<uint8_t> server_random;
1643
1644 uint16_t key_share_group_id = 0;
1645 Array<uint8_t> key_share_public_key;
1646 Array<uint8_t> key_share_secret;
1647
1648 uint16_t signature_algorithm = 0;
1649 Array<uint8_t> signature_input;
1650 Array<uint8_t> signature_spki;
1651 Array<uint8_t> signature;
1652
1653 Array<uint8_t> decrypted_psk;
1654 bool ignore_psk = false;
1655};
1656
1657struct SSL_HANDSHAKE {
1658 explicit SSL_HANDSHAKE(SSL *ssl);
1659 ~SSL_HANDSHAKE();
1660 static constexpr bool kAllowUniquePtr = true;
1661
1662 // ssl is a non-owning pointer to the parent |SSL| object.
1663 SSL *ssl;
1664
1665 // config is a non-owning pointer to the handshake configuration.
1666 SSL_CONFIG *config;
1667
1668 // wait contains the operation the handshake is currently blocking on or
1669 // |ssl_hs_ok| if none.
1670 enum ssl_hs_wait_t wait = ssl_hs_ok;
1671
1672 // state is the internal state for the TLS 1.2 and below handshake. Its
1673 // values depend on |do_handshake| but the starting state is always zero.
1674 int state = 0;
1675
1676 // tls13_state is the internal state for the TLS 1.3 handshake. Its values
1677 // depend on |do_handshake| but the starting state is always zero.
1678 int tls13_state = 0;
1679
1680 // min_version is the minimum accepted protocol version, taking account both
1681 // |SSL_OP_NO_*| and |SSL_CTX_set_min_proto_version| APIs.
1682 uint16_t min_version = 0;
1683
1684 // max_version is the maximum accepted protocol version, taking account both
1685 // |SSL_OP_NO_*| and |SSL_CTX_set_max_proto_version| APIs.
1686 uint16_t max_version = 0;
1687
1688 private:
1689 size_t hash_len_ = 0;
1690 uint8_t secret_[SSL_MAX_MD_SIZE] = {0};
1691 uint8_t early_traffic_secret_[SSL_MAX_MD_SIZE] = {0};
1692 uint8_t client_handshake_secret_[SSL_MAX_MD_SIZE] = {0};
1693 uint8_t server_handshake_secret_[SSL_MAX_MD_SIZE] = {0};
1694 uint8_t client_traffic_secret_0_[SSL_MAX_MD_SIZE] = {0};
1695 uint8_t server_traffic_secret_0_[SSL_MAX_MD_SIZE] = {0};
1696 uint8_t expected_client_finished_[SSL_MAX_MD_SIZE] = {0};
1697
1698 public:
1699 void ResizeSecrets(size_t hash_len);
1700
1701 // GetClientHello, on the server, returns either the normal ClientHello
1702 // message or the ClientHelloInner if it has been serialized to
1703 // |ech_client_hello_buf|. This function should only be called when the
1704 // current message is a ClientHello. It returns true on success and false on
1705 // error.
1706 //
1707 // Note that fields of the returned |out_msg| and |out_client_hello| point
1708 // into a handshake-owned buffer, so their lifetimes should not exceed this
1709 // SSL_HANDSHAKE.
1710 bool GetClientHello(SSLMessage *out_msg, SSL_CLIENT_HELLO *out_client_hello);
1711
1712 Span<uint8_t> secret() { return MakeSpan(secret_, hash_len_); }
1713 Span<uint8_t> early_traffic_secret() {
1714 return MakeSpan(early_traffic_secret_, hash_len_);
1715 }
1716 Span<uint8_t> client_handshake_secret() {
1717 return MakeSpan(client_handshake_secret_, hash_len_);
1718 }
1719 Span<uint8_t> server_handshake_secret() {
1720 return MakeSpan(server_handshake_secret_, hash_len_);
1721 }
1722 Span<uint8_t> client_traffic_secret_0() {
1723 return MakeSpan(client_traffic_secret_0_, hash_len_);
1724 }
1725 Span<uint8_t> server_traffic_secret_0() {
1726 return MakeSpan(server_traffic_secret_0_, hash_len_);
1727 }
1728 Span<uint8_t> expected_client_finished() {
1729 return MakeSpan(expected_client_finished_, hash_len_);
1730 }
1731
1732 union {
1733 // sent is a bitset where the bits correspond to elements of kExtensions
1734 // in t1_lib.c. Each bit is set if that extension was sent in a
1735 // ClientHello. It's not used by servers.
1736 uint32_t sent = 0;
1737 // received is a bitset, like |sent|, but is used by servers to record
1738 // which extensions were received from a client.
1739 uint32_t received;
1740 } extensions;
1741
1742 // retry_group is the group ID selected by the server in HelloRetryRequest in
1743 // TLS 1.3.
1744 uint16_t retry_group = 0;
1745
1746 // error, if |wait| is |ssl_hs_error|, is the error the handshake failed on.
1747 UniquePtr<ERR_SAVE_STATE> error;
1748
1749 // key_shares are the current key exchange instances. The second is only used
1750 // as a client if we believe that we should offer two key shares in a
1751 // ClientHello.
1752 UniquePtr<SSLKeyShare> key_shares[2];
1753
1754 // transcript is the current handshake transcript.
1755 SSLTranscript transcript;
1756
1757 // cookie is the value of the cookie received from the server, if any.
1758 Array<uint8_t> cookie;
1759
1760 // ech_grease contains the bytes of the GREASE ECH extension that was sent in
1761 // the first ClientHello.
1762 Array<uint8_t> ech_grease;
1763
1764 // ech_client_hello_buf, on the server, contains the bytes of the
1765 // reconstructed ClientHelloInner message.
1766 Array<uint8_t> ech_client_hello_buf;
1767
1768 // key_share_bytes is the value of the previously sent KeyShare extension by
1769 // the client in TLS 1.3.
1770 Array<uint8_t> key_share_bytes;
1771
1772 // ecdh_public_key, for servers, is the key share to be sent to the client in
1773 // TLS 1.3.
1774 Array<uint8_t> ecdh_public_key;
1775
1776 // peer_sigalgs are the signature algorithms that the peer supports. These are
1777 // taken from the contents of the signature algorithms extension for a server
1778 // or from the CertificateRequest for a client.
1779 Array<uint16_t> peer_sigalgs;
1780
1781 // peer_supported_group_list contains the supported group IDs advertised by
1782 // the peer. This is only set on the server's end. The server does not
1783 // advertise this extension to the client.
1784 Array<uint16_t> peer_supported_group_list;
1785
1786 // peer_delegated_credential_sigalgs are the signature algorithms the peer
1787 // supports with delegated credentials.
1788 Array<uint16_t> peer_delegated_credential_sigalgs;
1789
1790 // peer_key is the peer's ECDH key for a TLS 1.2 client.
1791 Array<uint8_t> peer_key;
1792
1793 // negotiated_token_binding_version is used by a server to store the
1794 // on-the-wire encoding of the Token Binding protocol version to advertise in
1795 // the ServerHello/EncryptedExtensions if the Token Binding extension is to be
1796 // sent.
1797 uint16_t negotiated_token_binding_version;
1798
1799 // cert_compression_alg_id, for a server, contains the negotiated certificate
1800 // compression algorithm for this client. It is only valid if
1801 // |cert_compression_negotiated| is true.
1802 uint16_t cert_compression_alg_id;
1803
1804 // ech_hpke_ctx, on the server, is the HPKE context used to decrypt the
1805 // client's ECH payloads.
1806 ScopedEVP_HPKE_CTX ech_hpke_ctx;
1807
1808 // server_params, in a TLS 1.2 server, stores the ServerKeyExchange
1809 // parameters. It has client and server randoms prepended for signing
1810 // convenience.
1811 Array<uint8_t> server_params;
1812
1813 // peer_psk_identity_hint, on the client, is the psk_identity_hint sent by the
1814 // server when using a TLS 1.2 PSK key exchange.
1815 UniquePtr<char> peer_psk_identity_hint;
1816
1817 // ca_names, on the client, contains the list of CAs received in a
1818 // CertificateRequest message.
1819 UniquePtr<STACK_OF(CRYPTO_BUFFER)> ca_names;
1820
1821 // cached_x509_ca_names contains a cache of parsed versions of the elements of
1822 // |ca_names|. This pointer is left non-owning so only
1823 // |ssl_crypto_x509_method| needs to link against crypto/x509.
1824 STACK_OF(X509_NAME) *cached_x509_ca_names = nullptr;
1825
1826 // certificate_types, on the client, contains the set of certificate types
1827 // received in a CertificateRequest message.
1828 Array<uint8_t> certificate_types;
1829
1830 // local_pubkey is the public key we are authenticating as.
1831 UniquePtr<EVP_PKEY> local_pubkey;
1832
1833 // peer_pubkey is the public key parsed from the peer's leaf certificate.
1834 UniquePtr<EVP_PKEY> peer_pubkey;
1835
1836 // new_session is the new mutable session being established by the current
1837 // handshake. It should not be cached.
1838 UniquePtr<SSL_SESSION> new_session;
1839
1840 // early_session is the session corresponding to the current 0-RTT state on
1841 // the client if |in_early_data| is true.
1842 UniquePtr<SSL_SESSION> early_session;
1843
1844 // ech_server_config_list, for servers, is the list of ECHConfig values that
1845 // were valid when the server received the first ClientHello. Its value will
1846 // not change when the config list on |SSL_CTX| is updated.
1847 UniquePtr<SSL_ECH_SERVER_CONFIG_LIST> ech_server_config_list;
1848
1849 // new_cipher is the cipher being negotiated in this handshake.
1850 const SSL_CIPHER *new_cipher = nullptr;
1851
1852 // key_block is the record-layer key block for TLS 1.2 and earlier.
1853 Array<uint8_t> key_block;
1854
1855 // hints contains the handshake hints for this connection. If
1856 // |hints_requested| is true, this field is non-null and contains the pending
1857 // hints to filled as the predicted handshake progresses. Otherwise, this
1858 // field, if non-null, contains hints configured by the caller and will
1859 // influence the handshake on match.
1860 UniquePtr<SSL_HANDSHAKE_HINTS> hints;
1861
1862 // ech_accept, on the server, indicates whether the server negotiated ECH and
1863 // is handshaking with the inner ClientHello.
1864 bool ech_accept : 1;
1865
1866 // ech_present, on the server, indicates whether the ClientHello contained an
1867 // encrypted_client_hello extension.
1868 bool ech_present : 1;
1869
1870 // ech_is_inner_present, on the server, indicates whether the ClientHello
1871 // contained an ech_is_inner extension.
1872 bool ech_is_inner_present : 1;
1873
1874 // scts_requested is true if the SCT extension is in the ClientHello.
1875 bool scts_requested : 1;
1876
1877 // needs_psk_binder is true if the ClientHello has a placeholder PSK binder to
1878 // be filled in.
1879 bool needs_psk_binder : 1;
1880
1881 // handshake_finalized is true once the handshake has completed, at which
1882 // point accessors should use the established state.
1883 bool handshake_finalized : 1;
1884
1885 // accept_psk_mode stores whether the client's PSK mode is compatible with our
1886 // preferences.
1887 bool accept_psk_mode : 1;
1888
1889 // cert_request is true if a client certificate was requested.
1890 bool cert_request : 1;
1891
1892 // certificate_status_expected is true if OCSP stapling was negotiated and the
1893 // server is expected to send a CertificateStatus message. (This is used on
1894 // both the client and server sides.)
1895 bool certificate_status_expected : 1;
1896
1897 // ocsp_stapling_requested is true if a client requested OCSP stapling.
1898 bool ocsp_stapling_requested : 1;
1899
1900 // delegated_credential_requested is true if the peer indicated support for
1901 // the delegated credential extension.
1902 bool delegated_credential_requested : 1;
1903
1904 // should_ack_sni is used by a server and indicates that the SNI extension
1905 // should be echoed in the ServerHello.
1906 bool should_ack_sni : 1;
1907
1908 // in_false_start is true if there is a pending client handshake in False
1909 // Start. The client may write data at this point.
1910 bool in_false_start : 1;
1911
1912 // in_early_data is true if there is a pending handshake that has progressed
1913 // enough to send and receive early data.
1914 bool in_early_data : 1;
1915
1916 // early_data_offered is true if the client sent the early_data extension.
1917 bool early_data_offered : 1;
1918
1919 // can_early_read is true if application data may be read at this point in the
1920 // handshake.
1921 bool can_early_read : 1;
1922
1923 // can_early_write is true if application data may be written at this point in
1924 // the handshake.
1925 bool can_early_write : 1;
1926
1927 // next_proto_neg_seen is one of NPN was negotiated.
1928 bool next_proto_neg_seen : 1;
1929
1930 // ticket_expected is true if a TLS 1.2 NewSessionTicket message is to be sent
1931 // or received.
1932 bool ticket_expected : 1;
1933
1934 // extended_master_secret is true if the extended master secret extension is
1935 // negotiated in this handshake.
1936 bool extended_master_secret : 1;
1937
1938 // pending_private_key_op is true if there is a pending private key operation
1939 // in progress.
1940 bool pending_private_key_op : 1;
1941
1942 // grease_seeded is true if |grease_seed| has been initialized.
1943 bool grease_seeded : 1;
1944
1945 // handback indicates that a server should pause the handshake after
1946 // finishing operations that require private key material, in such a way that
1947 // |SSL_get_error| returns |SSL_ERROR_HANDBACK|. It is set by
1948 // |SSL_apply_handoff|.
1949 bool handback : 1;
1950
1951 // hints_requested indicates the caller has requested handshake hints. Only
1952 // the first round-trip of the handshake will complete, after which the
1953 // |hints| structure can be serialized.
1954 bool hints_requested : 1;
1955
1956 // cert_compression_negotiated is true iff |cert_compression_alg_id| is valid.
1957 bool cert_compression_negotiated : 1;
1958
1959 // apply_jdk11_workaround is true if the peer is probably a JDK 11 client
1960 // which implemented TLS 1.3 incorrectly.
1961 bool apply_jdk11_workaround : 1;
1962
1963 // can_release_private_key is true if the private key will no longer be used
1964 // in this handshake.
1965 bool can_release_private_key : 1;
1966
1967 // client_version is the value sent or received in the ClientHello version.
1968 uint16_t client_version = 0;
1969
1970 // early_data_read is the amount of early data that has been read by the
1971 // record layer.
1972 uint16_t early_data_read = 0;
1973
1974 // early_data_written is the amount of early data that has been written by the
1975 // record layer.
1976 uint16_t early_data_written = 0;
1977
1978 // ech_config_id is the ECH config sent by the client.
1979 uint8_t ech_config_id = 0;
1980
1981 // session_id is the session ID in the ClientHello.
1982 uint8_t session_id[SSL_MAX_SSL_SESSION_ID_LENGTH] = {0};
1983 uint8_t session_id_len = 0;
1984
1985 // grease_seed is the entropy for GREASE values. It is valid if
1986 // |grease_seeded| is true.
1987 uint8_t grease_seed[ssl_grease_last_index + 1] = {0};
1988};
1989
1990UniquePtr<SSL_HANDSHAKE> ssl_handshake_new(SSL *ssl);

1992// ssl_check_message_type checks if |msg| has type |type|. If so it returns
1993// one. Otherwise, it sends an alert and returns zero.
1994bool ssl_check_message_type(SSL *ssl, const SSLMessage &msg, int type);
1995
1996// ssl_run_handshake runs the TLS handshake. It returns one on success and <= 0
1997// on error. It sets |out_early_return| to one if we've completed the handshake
1998// early.
1999int ssl_run_handshake(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs, bool *out_early_return);

2076// tls13_get_cert_verify_signature_input generates the message to be signed for
2077// TLS 1.3's CertificateVerify message. |cert_verify_context| determines the
2078// type of signature. It sets |*out| to a newly allocated buffer containing the

2110// ssl_parse_extensions parses a TLS extensions block out of |cbs| and advances
2111// it. It writes the parsed extensions to pointers denoted by |ext_types|. On
2112// success, it fills in the |out_present| and |out_data| fields and returns
2113// true. Otherwise, it sets |*out_alert| to an alert to send and returns false.
2114// Unknown extensions are rejected unless |ignore_unknown| is true.
2115bool ssl_parse_extensions(const CBS *cbs, uint8_t *out_alert,
2116 Span<const SSL_EXTENSION_TYPE> ext_types,
2117 bool ignore_unknown);

2124 bool send_alert);

2158// GREASE.
2159
2160// ssl_get_grease_value returns a GREASE value for |hs|. For a given
2161// connection, the values for each index will be deterministic. This allows the
2162// same ClientHello be sent twice for a HelloRetryRequest or the same group be
2163// advertised in both supported_groups and key_shares.
2164uint16_t ssl_get_grease_value(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs, enum ssl_grease_index_t index);
2165

2167// Signature algorithms.
2168
2169// tls1_parse_peer_sigalgs parses |sigalgs| as the list of peer signature
2170// algorithms and saves them on |hs|. It returns true on success and false on
2171// error.
2172bool tls1_parse_peer_sigalgs(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs, const CBS *sigalgs);
2173
2174// tls1_get_legacy_signature_algorithm sets |*out| to the signature algorithm
2175// that should be used with |pkey| in TLS 1.1 and earlier. It returns true on
2176// success and false if |pkey| may not be used at those versions.
2177bool tls1_get_legacy_signature_algorithm(uint16_t *out, const EVP_PKEY *pkey);
2178
2179// tls1_choose_signature_algorithm sets |*out| to a signature algorithm for use
2180// with |hs|'s private key based on the peer's preferences and the algorithms
2181// supported. It returns true on success and false on error.
2182bool tls1_choose_signature_algorithm(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs, uint16_t *out);
2183
2184// tls1_get_peer_verify_algorithms returns the signature schemes for which the
2185// peer indicated support.
2186//
2187// NOTE: The related function |SSL_get0_peer_verify_algorithms| only has
2188// well-defined behavior during the callbacks set by |SSL_CTX_set_cert_cb| and
2189// |SSL_CTX_set_client_cert_cb|, or when the handshake is paused because of
2190// them.
2191Span<const uint16_t> tls1_get_peer_verify_algorithms(const SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs);
2192
2193// tls12_add_verify_sigalgs adds the signature algorithms acceptable for the
2194// peer signature to |out|. It returns true on success and false on error.
2195bool tls12_add_verify_sigalgs(const SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs, CBB *out);
2196
2197// tls12_check_peer_sigalg checks if |sigalg| is acceptable for the peer
2198// signature. It returns true on success and false on error, setting
2199// |*out_alert| to an alert to send.
2200bool tls12_check_peer_sigalg(const SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs, uint8_t *out_alert,
2201 uint16_t sigalg);
