2204// Underdocumented functions.
2205//
2206// Functions below here haven't been touched up and may be underdocumented.
2207
2208#define TLSEXT_CHANNEL_ID_SIZE 128
2209
2210// From RFC4492, used in encoding the curve type in ECParameters
2211#define NAMED_CURVE_TYPE 3
2212
2213struct CERT {
2214 static constexpr bool kAllowUniquePtr = true;
2215
2216 explicit CERT(const SSL_X509_METHOD *x509_method);
2217 ~CERT();
2218
2219 UniquePtr<EVP_PKEY> privatekey;
2220
2221 // chain contains the certificate chain, with the leaf at the beginning. The
2222 // first element of |chain| may be NULL to indicate that the leaf certificate
2223 // has not yet been set.
2224 // If |chain| != NULL -> len(chain) >= 1
2225 // If |chain[0]| == NULL -> len(chain) >= 2.
2226 // |chain[1..]| != NULL
2227 UniquePtr<STACK_OF(CRYPTO_BUFFER)> chain;
2228
2229 // x509_chain may contain a parsed copy of |chain[1..]|. This is only used as
2230 // a cache in order to implement get0 functions that return a non-owning
2231 // pointer to the certificate chain.
2232 STACK_OF(X509) *x509_chain = nullptr;
2233
2234 // x509_leaf may contain a parsed copy of the first element of |chain|. This
2235 // is only used as a cache in order to implement get0 functions that return
2236 // a non-owning pointer to the certificate chain.
2237 X509 *x509_leaf = nullptr;
2238
2239 // x509_stash contains the last |X509| object append to the chain. This is a
2240 // workaround for some third-party code that continue to use an |X509| object
2241 // even after passing ownership with an add0 function.
2242 X509 *x509_stash = nullptr;
2243
2244 // key_method, if non-NULL, is a set of callbacks to call for private key
2245 // operations.
2246 const SSL_PRIVATE_KEY_METHOD *key_method = nullptr;
2247
2248 // x509_method contains pointers to functions that might deal with |X509|
2249 // compatibility, or might be a no-op, depending on the application.
2250 const SSL_X509_METHOD *x509_method = nullptr;
2251
2252 // sigalgs, if non-empty, is the set of signature algorithms supported by
2253 // |privatekey| in decreasing order of preference.
2254 Array<uint16_t> sigalgs;
2255
2256 // Certificate setup callback: if set is called whenever a
2257 // certificate may be required (client or server). the callback
2258 // can then examine any appropriate parameters and setup any
2259 // certificates required. This allows advanced applications
2260 // to select certificates on the fly: for example based on
2261 // supported signature algorithms or curves.
2262 int (*cert_cb)(SSL *ssl, void *arg) = nullptr;
2263 void *cert_cb_arg = nullptr;
2264
2265 // Optional X509_STORE for certificate validation. If NULL the parent SSL_CTX
2266 // store is used instead.
2267 X509_STORE *verify_store = nullptr;
2268
2269 // Signed certificate timestamp list to be sent to the client, if requested
2270 UniquePtr<CRYPTO_BUFFER> signed_cert_timestamp_list;
2271
2272 // OCSP response to be sent to the client, if requested.
2273 UniquePtr<CRYPTO_BUFFER> ocsp_response;
2274
2275 // sid_ctx partitions the session space within a shared session cache or
2276 // ticket key. Only sessions with a matching value will be accepted.
2277 uint8_t sid_ctx_length = 0;
2278 uint8_t sid_ctx[SSL_MAX_SID_CTX_LENGTH] = {0};
2279
2280 // Delegated credentials.
2281
2282 // dc is the delegated credential to send to the peer (if requested).
2283 UniquePtr<DC> dc = nullptr;
2284
2285 // dc_privatekey is used instead of |privatekey| or |key_method| to
2286 // authenticate the host if a delegated credential is used in the handshake.
2287 UniquePtr<EVP_PKEY> dc_privatekey = nullptr;
2288
2289 // dc_key_method, if not NULL, is used instead of |dc_privatekey| to
2290 // authenticate the host.
2291 const SSL_PRIVATE_KEY_METHOD *dc_key_method = nullptr;
2292};
2293
2294// |SSL_PROTOCOL_METHOD| abstracts between TLS and DTLS.
2295struct SSL_PROTOCOL_METHOD {
2296 bool is_dtls;
2297 bool (*ssl_new)(SSL *ssl);
2298 void (*ssl_free)(SSL *ssl);
2299 // get_message sets |*out| to the current handshake message and returns true
2300 // if one has been received. It returns false if more input is needed.
2301 bool (*get_message)(const SSL *ssl, SSLMessage *out);
2302 // next_message is called to release the current handshake message.
2303 void (*next_message)(SSL *ssl);
2304 // has_unprocessed_handshake_data returns whether there is buffered
2305 // handshake data that has not been consumed by |get_message|.
2306 bool (*has_unprocessed_handshake_data)(const SSL *ssl);
2307 // Use the |ssl_open_handshake| wrapper.
2308 ssl_open_record_t (*open_handshake)(SSL *ssl, size_t *out_consumed,
2309 uint8_t *out_alert, Span<uint8_t> in);
2310 // Use the |ssl_open_change_cipher_spec| wrapper.
2311 ssl_open_record_t (*open_change_cipher_spec)(SSL *ssl, size_t *out_consumed,
2312 uint8_t *out_alert,
2313 Span<uint8_t> in);
2314 // Use the |ssl_open_app_data| wrapper.
2315 ssl_open_record_t (*open_app_data)(SSL *ssl, Span<uint8_t> *out,
2316 size_t *out_consumed, uint8_t *out_alert,
2317 Span<uint8_t> in);
2318 int (*write_app_data)(SSL *ssl, bool *out_needs_handshake, const uint8_t *buf,
2319 int len);
2320 int (*dispatch_alert)(SSL *ssl);
2321 // init_message begins a new handshake message of type |type|. |cbb| is the
2322 // root CBB to be passed into |finish_message|. |*body| is set to a child CBB
2323 // the caller should write to. It returns true on success and false on error.
2324 bool (*init_message)(SSL *ssl, CBB *cbb, CBB *body, uint8_t type);
2325 // finish_message finishes a handshake message. It sets |*out_msg| to the
2326 // serialized message. It returns true on success and false on error.
2327 bool (*finish_message)(SSL *ssl, CBB *cbb, bssl::Array<uint8_t> *out_msg);
2328 // add_message adds a handshake message to the pending flight. It returns
2329 // true on success and false on error.
2330 bool (*add_message)(SSL *ssl, bssl::Array<uint8_t> msg);
2331 // add_change_cipher_spec adds a ChangeCipherSpec record to the pending
2332 // flight. It returns true on success and false on error.
2333 bool (*add_change_cipher_spec)(SSL *ssl);
2334 // flush_flight flushes the pending flight to the transport. It returns one on
2335 // success and <= 0 on error.
2336 int (*flush_flight)(SSL *ssl);
2337 // on_handshake_complete is called when the handshake is complete.
2338 void (*on_handshake_complete)(SSL *ssl);
2339 // set_read_state sets |ssl|'s read cipher state and level to |aead_ctx| and
2340 // |level|. In QUIC, |aead_ctx| is a placeholder object and |secret_for_quic|
2341 // is the original secret. This function returns true on success and false on
2342 // error.
2343 bool (*set_read_state)(SSL *ssl, ssl_encryption_level_t level,
2344 UniquePtr<SSLAEADContext> aead_ctx,
2345 Span<const uint8_t> secret_for_quic);
2346 // set_write_state sets |ssl|'s write cipher state and level to |aead_ctx| and
2347 // |level|. In QUIC, |aead_ctx| is a placeholder object and |secret_for_quic|
2348 // is the original secret. This function returns true on success and false on
2349 // error.
2350 bool (*set_write_state)(SSL *ssl, ssl_encryption_level_t level,
2351 UniquePtr<SSLAEADContext> aead_ctx,
2352 Span<const uint8_t> secret_for_quic);
2353};
2354
2355// The following wrappers call |open_*| but handle |read_shutdown| correctly.
2356
2357// ssl_open_handshake processes a record from |in| for reading a handshake
2358// message.
2359ssl_open_record_t ssl_open_handshake(SSL *ssl, size_t *out_consumed,
2360 uint8_t *out_alert, Span<uint8_t> in);
2361
2362// ssl_open_change_cipher_spec processes a record from |in| for reading a
2363// ChangeCipherSpec.
2364ssl_open_record_t ssl_open_change_cipher_spec(SSL *ssl, size_t *out_consumed,
2365 uint8_t *out_alert,
2366 Span<uint8_t> in);
2367
2368// ssl_open_app_data processes a record from |in| for reading application data.
2369// On success, it returns |ssl_open_record_success| and sets |*out| to the
2370// input. If it encounters a post-handshake message, it returns
2371// |ssl_open_record_discard|. The caller should then retry, after processing any
2372// messages received with |get_message|.
2373ssl_open_record_t ssl_open_app_data(SSL *ssl, Span<uint8_t> *out,
2374 size_t *out_consumed, uint8_t *out_alert,
2375 Span<uint8_t> in);
2376
2377struct SSL_X509_METHOD {
2378 // check_client_CA_list returns one if |names| is a good list of X.509
2379 // distinguished names and zero otherwise. This is used to ensure that we can
2380 // reject unparsable values at handshake time when using crypto/x509.
2381 bool (*check_client_CA_list)(STACK_OF(CRYPTO_BUFFER) *names);
2382
2383 // cert_clear frees and NULLs all X509 certificate-related state.
2384 void (*cert_clear)(CERT *cert);
2385 // cert_free frees all X509-related state.
2386 void (*cert_free)(CERT *cert);
2387 // cert_flush_cached_chain drops any cached |X509|-based certificate chain
2388 // from |cert|.
2389 // cert_dup duplicates any needed fields from |cert| to |new_cert|.
2390 void (*cert_dup)(CERT *new_cert, const CERT *cert);
2391 void (*cert_flush_cached_chain)(CERT *cert);
2392 // cert_flush_cached_chain drops any cached |X509|-based leaf certificate
2393 // from |cert|.
2394 void (*cert_flush_cached_leaf)(CERT *cert);
2395
2396 // session_cache_objects fills out |sess->x509_peer| and |sess->x509_chain|
2397 // from |sess->certs| and erases |sess->x509_chain_without_leaf|. It returns
2398 // true on success or false on error.
2399 bool (*session_cache_objects)(SSL_SESSION *session);
2400 // session_dup duplicates any needed fields from |session| to |new_session|.
2401 // It returns true on success or false on error.
2402 bool (*session_dup)(SSL_SESSION *new_session, const SSL_SESSION *session);
2403 // session_clear frees any X509-related state from |session|.
2404 void (*session_clear)(SSL_SESSION *session);
2405 // session_verify_cert_chain verifies the certificate chain in |session|,
2406 // sets |session->verify_result| and returns true on success or false on
2407 // error.
2408 bool (*session_verify_cert_chain)(SSL_SESSION *session, SSL_HANDSHAKE *ssl,
2409 uint8_t *out_alert);
2410
2411 // hs_flush_cached_ca_names drops any cached |X509_NAME|s from |hs|.
2412 void (*hs_flush_cached_ca_names)(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs);
2413 // ssl_new does any necessary initialisation of |hs|. It returns true on
2414 // success or false on error.
2415 bool (*ssl_new)(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs);
2416 // ssl_free frees anything created by |ssl_new|.
2417 void (*ssl_config_free)(SSL_CONFIG *cfg);
2418 // ssl_flush_cached_client_CA drops any cached |X509_NAME|s from |ssl|.
2419 void (*ssl_flush_cached_client_CA)(SSL_CONFIG *cfg);
2420 // ssl_auto_chain_if_needed runs the deprecated auto-chaining logic if
2421 // necessary. On success, it updates |ssl|'s certificate configuration as
2422 // needed and returns true. Otherwise, it returns false.
2423 bool (*ssl_auto_chain_if_needed)(SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs);
2424 // ssl_ctx_new does any necessary initialisation of |ctx|. It returns true on
2425 // success or false on error.
2426 bool (*ssl_ctx_new)(SSL_CTX *ctx);
2427 // ssl_ctx_free frees anything created by |ssl_ctx_new|.
2428 void (*ssl_ctx_free)(SSL_CTX *ctx);
2429 // ssl_ctx_flush_cached_client_CA drops any cached |X509_NAME|s from |ctx|.
2430 void (*ssl_ctx_flush_cached_client_CA)(SSL_CTX *ssl);
2431};
2432
2433// ssl_crypto_x509_method provides the |SSL_X509_METHOD| functions using
2434// crypto/x509.
2435extern const SSL_X509_METHOD ssl_crypto_x509_method;
2436
2437// ssl_noop_x509_method provides the |SSL_X509_METHOD| functions that avoid
2438// crypto/x509.
2439extern const SSL_X509_METHOD ssl_noop_x509_method;
2440
2441struct TicketKey {
2442 static constexpr bool kAllowUniquePtr = true;
2443
2444 uint8_t name[SSL_TICKET_KEY_NAME_LEN] = {0};
2445 uint8_t hmac_key[16] = {0};
2446 uint8_t aes_key[16] = {0};
2447 // next_rotation_tv_sec is the time (in seconds from the epoch) when the
2448 // current key should be superseded by a new key, or the time when a previous
2449 // key should be dropped. If zero, then the key should not be automatically
2450 // rotated.
2451 uint64_t next_rotation_tv_sec = 0;
2452};

2454struct CertCompressionAlg {
2455 static constexpr bool kAllowUniquePtr = true;
2456
2457 ssl_cert_compression_func_t compress = nullptr;
2458 ssl_cert_decompression_func_t decompress = nullptr;
2459 uint16_t alg_id = 0;
2460};

2468// An ssl_shutdown_t describes the shutdown state of one end of the connection,
2469// whether it is alive or has been shutdown via close_notify or fatal alert.
2470enum ssl_shutdown_t {
2471 ssl_shutdown_none = 0,
2472 ssl_shutdown_close_notify = 1,
2473 ssl_shutdown_error = 2,
2474};
2475
2476struct SSL3_STATE {
2477 static constexpr bool kAllowUniquePtr = true;
2478
2479 SSL3_STATE();
2480 ~SSL3_STATE();
2481
2482 uint8_t read_sequence[8] = {0};
2483 uint8_t write_sequence[8] = {0};
2484
2485 uint8_t server_random[SSL3_RANDOM_SIZE] = {0};
2486 uint8_t client_random[SSL3_RANDOM_SIZE] = {0};
2487
2488 // read_buffer holds data from the transport to be processed.
2489 SSLBuffer read_buffer;
2490 // write_buffer holds data to be written to the transport.
2491 SSLBuffer write_buffer;
2492
2493 // pending_app_data is the unconsumed application data. It points into
2494 // |read_buffer|.
2495 Span<uint8_t> pending_app_data;
2496
2497 // partial write - check the numbers match
2498 unsigned int wnum = 0; // number of bytes sent so far
2499 int wpend_tot = 0; // number bytes written
2500 int wpend_type = 0;
2501 int wpend_ret = 0; // number of bytes submitted
2502 const uint8_t *wpend_buf = nullptr;
2503
2504 // read_shutdown is the shutdown state for the read half of the connection.
2505 enum ssl_shutdown_t read_shutdown = ssl_shutdown_none;
2506
2507 // write_shutdown is the shutdown state for the write half of the connection.
2508 enum ssl_shutdown_t write_shutdown = ssl_shutdown_none;
2509
2510 // read_error, if |read_shutdown| is |ssl_shutdown_error|, is the error for
2511 // the receive half of the connection.
2512 UniquePtr<ERR_SAVE_STATE> read_error;
2513
2514 int total_renegotiations = 0;
2515
2516 // This holds a variable that indicates what we were doing when a 0 or -1 is
2517 // returned. This is needed for non-blocking IO so we know what request
2518 // needs re-doing when in SSL_accept or SSL_connect
2519 int rwstate = SSL_ERROR_NONE;
2520
2521 enum ssl_encryption_level_t read_level = ssl_encryption_initial;
2522 enum ssl_encryption_level_t write_level = ssl_encryption_initial;
2523
2524 // early_data_skipped is the amount of early data that has been skipped by the
2525 // record layer.
2526 uint16_t early_data_skipped = 0;
2527
2528 // empty_record_count is the number of consecutive empty records received.
2529 uint8_t empty_record_count = 0;
2530
2531 // warning_alert_count is the number of consecutive warning alerts
2532 // received.
2533 uint8_t warning_alert_count = 0;
2534
2535 // key_update_count is the number of consecutive KeyUpdates received.
2536 uint8_t key_update_count = 0;
2537
2538 // The negotiated Token Binding key parameter. Only valid if
2539 // |token_binding_negotiated| is set.
2540 uint8_t negotiated_token_binding_param = 0;
2541
2542 // skip_early_data instructs the record layer to skip unexpected early data
2543 // messages when 0RTT is rejected.
2544 bool skip_early_data : 1;
2545
2546 // have_version is true if the connection's final version is known. Otherwise
2547 // the version has not been negotiated yet.
2548 bool have_version : 1;
2549
2550 // v2_hello_done is true if the peer's V2ClientHello, if any, has been handled
2551 // and future messages should use the record layer.
2552 bool v2_hello_done : 1;
2553
2554 // is_v2_hello is true if the current handshake message was derived from a
2555 // V2ClientHello rather than received from the peer directly.
2556 bool is_v2_hello : 1;
2557
2558 // has_message is true if the current handshake message has been returned
2559 // at least once by |get_message| and false otherwise.
2560 bool has_message : 1;
2561
2562 // initial_handshake_complete is true if the initial handshake has
2563 // completed.
2564 bool initial_handshake_complete : 1;
2565
2566 // session_reused indicates whether a session was resumed.
2567 bool session_reused : 1;
2568
2569 // delegated_credential_used is whether we presented a delegated credential to
2570 // the peer.
2571 bool delegated_credential_used : 1;
2572
2573 bool send_connection_binding : 1;
2574
2575 // In a client, this means that the server supported Channel ID and that a
2576 // Channel ID was sent. In a server it means that we echoed support for
2577 // Channel IDs and that |channel_id| will be valid after the handshake.
2578 bool channel_id_valid : 1;
2579
2580 // key_update_pending is true if we have a KeyUpdate acknowledgment
2581 // outstanding.
2582 bool key_update_pending : 1;
2583
2584 // wpend_pending is true if we have a pending write outstanding.
2585 bool wpend_pending : 1;
2586
2587 // early_data_accepted is true if early data was accepted by the server.
2588 bool early_data_accepted : 1;
2589
2590 // token_binding_negotiated is set if Token Binding was negotiated.
2591 bool token_binding_negotiated : 1;
2592
2593 // alert_dispatch is true there is an alert in |send_alert| to be sent.
2594 bool alert_dispatch : 1;
2595
2596 // renegotiate_pending is whether the read half of the channel is blocked on a
2597 // HelloRequest.
2598 bool renegotiate_pending : 1;
2599
2600 // used_hello_retry_request is whether the handshake used a TLS 1.3
2601 // HelloRetryRequest message.
2602 bool used_hello_retry_request : 1;
2603
2604 // hs_buf is the buffer of handshake data to process.
2605 UniquePtr<BUF_MEM> hs_buf;
2606
2607 // pending_hs_data contains the pending handshake data that has not yet
2608 // been encrypted to |pending_flight|. This allows packing the handshake into
2609 // fewer records.
2610 UniquePtr<BUF_MEM> pending_hs_data;
2611
2612 // pending_flight is the pending outgoing flight. This is used to flush each
2613 // handshake flight in a single write. |write_buffer| must be written out
2614 // before this data.
2615 UniquePtr<BUF_MEM> pending_flight;
2616
2617 // pending_flight_offset is the number of bytes of |pending_flight| which have
2618 // been successfully written.
2619 uint32_t pending_flight_offset = 0;
2620
2621 // ticket_age_skew is the difference, in seconds, between the client-sent
2622 // ticket age and the server-computed value in TLS 1.3 server connections
2623 // which resumed a session.
2624 int32_t ticket_age_skew = 0;
2625
2626 // ssl_early_data_reason stores details on why 0-RTT was accepted or rejected.
2627 enum ssl_early_data_reason_t early_data_reason = ssl_early_data_unknown;
2628
2629 // aead_read_ctx is the current read cipher state.
2630 UniquePtr<SSLAEADContext> aead_read_ctx;
2631
2632 // aead_write_ctx is the current write cipher state.
2633 UniquePtr<SSLAEADContext> aead_write_ctx;
2634
2635 // hs is the handshake state for the current handshake or NULL if there isn't
2636 // one.
2637 UniquePtr<SSL_HANDSHAKE> hs;
2638
2639 uint8_t write_traffic_secret[SSL_MAX_MD_SIZE] = {0};
2640 uint8_t read_traffic_secret[SSL_MAX_MD_SIZE] = {0};
2641 uint8_t exporter_secret[SSL_MAX_MD_SIZE] = {0};
2642 uint8_t write_traffic_secret_len = 0;
2643 uint8_t read_traffic_secret_len = 0;
2644 uint8_t exporter_secret_len = 0;
2645
2646 // Connection binding to prevent renegotiation attacks
2647 uint8_t previous_client_finished[12] = {0};
2648 uint8_t previous_client_finished_len = 0;
2649 uint8_t previous_server_finished_len = 0;
2650 uint8_t previous_server_finished[12] = {0};
2651
2652 uint8_t send_alert[2] = {0};
2653
2654 // established_session is the session established by the connection. This
2655 // session is only filled upon the completion of the handshake and is
2656 // immutable.
2657 UniquePtr<SSL_SESSION> established_session;
2658
2659 // Next protocol negotiation. For the client, this is the protocol that we
2660 // sent in NextProtocol and is set when handling ServerHello extensions.
2661 //
2662 // For a server, this is the client's selected_protocol from NextProtocol and
2663 // is set when handling the NextProtocol message, before the Finished
2664 // message.
2665 Array<uint8_t> next_proto_negotiated;
2666
2667 // ALPN information
2668 // (we are in the process of transitioning from NPN to ALPN.)
2669
2670 // In a server these point to the selected ALPN protocol after the
2671 // ClientHello has been processed. In a client these contain the protocol
2672 // that the server selected once the ServerHello has been processed.
2673 Array<uint8_t> alpn_selected;
2674
2675 // hostname, on the server, is the value of the SNI extension.
2676 UniquePtr<char> hostname;
2677
2678 // For a server:
2679 // If |channel_id_valid| is true, then this contains the
2680 // verified Channel ID from the client: a P256 point, (x,y), where
2681 // each are big-endian values.
2682 uint8_t channel_id[64] = {0};
2683
2684 // Contains the QUIC transport params received by the peer.
2685 Array<uint8_t> peer_quic_transport_params;
2686
2687 // srtp_profile is the selected SRTP protection profile for
2688 // DTLS-SRTP.
2689 const SRTP_PROTECTION_PROFILE *srtp_profile = nullptr;
2690};
2691
2692// lengths of messages
2693#define DTLS1_COOKIE_LENGTH 256
2694
2695#define DTLS1_RT_HEADER_LENGTH 13
2696
2697#define DTLS1_HM_HEADER_LENGTH 12
2698
2699#define DTLS1_CCS_HEADER_LENGTH 1
2700
2701#define DTLS1_AL_HEADER_LENGTH 2
2702
2703struct hm_header_st {
2704 uint8_t type;
2705 uint32_t msg_len;
2706 uint16_t seq;
2707 uint32_t frag_off;
2708 uint32_t frag_len;
2709};
2710
2711// An hm_fragment is an incoming DTLS message, possibly not yet assembled.
2712struct hm_fragment {
2713 static constexpr bool kAllowUniquePtr = true;
2714
2715 hm_fragment() {}
2716 hm_fragment(const hm_fragment &) = delete;
2717 hm_fragment &operator=(const hm_fragment &) = delete;
2718
2719 ~hm_fragment();
2720
2721 // type is the type of the message.
2722 uint8_t type = 0;
2723 // seq is the sequence number of this message.
2724 uint16_t seq = 0;
2725 // msg_len is the length of the message body.
2726 uint32_t msg_len = 0;
2727 // data is a pointer to the message, including message header. It has length
2728 // |DTLS1_HM_HEADER_LENGTH| + |msg_len|.
2729 uint8_t *data = nullptr;
2730 // reassembly is a bitmask of |msg_len| bits corresponding to which parts of
2731 // the message have been received. It is NULL if the message is complete.
2732 uint8_t *reassembly = nullptr;
2733};
2734
2735struct OPENSSL_timeval {
2736 uint64_t tv_sec;
2737 uint32_t tv_usec;
2738};
2739
2740struct DTLS1_STATE {
2741 static constexpr bool kAllowUniquePtr = true;
2742
2743 DTLS1_STATE();
2744 ~DTLS1_STATE();
2745
2746 // has_change_cipher_spec is true if we have received a ChangeCipherSpec from
2747 // the peer in this epoch.
2748 bool has_change_cipher_spec : 1;
2749
2750 // outgoing_messages_complete is true if |outgoing_messages| has been
2751 // completed by an attempt to flush it. Future calls to |add_message| and
2752 // |add_change_cipher_spec| will start a new flight.
2753 bool outgoing_messages_complete : 1;
2754
2755 // flight_has_reply is true if the current outgoing flight is complete and has
2756 // processed at least one message. This is used to detect whether we or the
2757 // peer sent the final flight.
2758 bool flight_has_reply : 1;
2759
2760 uint8_t cookie[DTLS1_COOKIE_LENGTH] = {0};
2761 size_t cookie_len = 0;
2762
2763 // The current data and handshake epoch. This is initially undefined, and
2764 // starts at zero once the initial handshake is completed.
2765 uint16_t r_epoch = 0;
2766 uint16_t w_epoch = 0;
2767
2768 // records being received in the current epoch
2769 DTLS1_BITMAP bitmap;
2770
2771 uint16_t handshake_write_seq = 0;
2772 uint16_t handshake_read_seq = 0;
2773
2774 // save last sequence number for retransmissions
2775 uint8_t last_write_sequence[8] = {0};
2776 UniquePtr<SSLAEADContext> last_aead_write_ctx;
2777
2778 // incoming_messages is a ring buffer of incoming handshake messages that have
2779 // yet to be processed. The front of the ring buffer is message number
2780 // |handshake_read_seq|, at position |handshake_read_seq| %
2781 // |SSL_MAX_HANDSHAKE_FLIGHT|.
2782 UniquePtr<hm_fragment> incoming_messages[SSL_MAX_HANDSHAKE_FLIGHT];
2783
2784 // outgoing_messages is the queue of outgoing messages from the last handshake
2785 // flight.
2786 DTLS_OUTGOING_MESSAGE outgoing_messages[SSL_MAX_HANDSHAKE_FLIGHT];
2787 uint8_t outgoing_messages_len = 0;
2788
2789 // outgoing_written is the number of outgoing messages that have been
2790 // written.
2791 uint8_t outgoing_written = 0;
2792 // outgoing_offset is the number of bytes of the next outgoing message have
2793 // been written.
2794 uint32_t outgoing_offset = 0;
2795
2796 unsigned mtu = 0; // max DTLS packet size
2797
2798 // num_timeouts is the number of times the retransmit timer has fired since
2799 // the last time it was reset.
2800 unsigned num_timeouts = 0;
2801
2802 // Indicates when the last handshake msg or heartbeat sent will
2803 // timeout.
2804 struct OPENSSL_timeval next_timeout = {0, 0};
2805
2806 // timeout_duration_ms is the timeout duration in milliseconds.
2807 unsigned timeout_duration_ms = 0;
2808};
2809
2810// An ALPSConfig is a pair of ALPN protocol and settings value to use with ALPS.
2811struct ALPSConfig {
2812 Array<uint8_t> protocol;
2813 Array<uint8_t> settings;
2814};
2815
2816// SSL_CONFIG contains configuration bits that can be shed after the handshake
2817// completes. Objects of this type are not shared; they are unique to a
2818// particular |SSL|.
2819//
2820// See SSL_shed_handshake_config() for more about the conditions under which
2821// configuration can be shed.
2822struct SSL_CONFIG {
2823 static constexpr bool kAllowUniquePtr = true;
2824
2825 explicit SSL_CONFIG(SSL *ssl_arg);
2826 ~SSL_CONFIG();
2827
2828 // ssl is a non-owning pointer to the parent |SSL| object.
2829 SSL *const ssl = nullptr;
2830
2831 // conf_max_version is the maximum acceptable version configured by
2832 // |SSL_set_max_proto_version|. Note this version is not normalized in DTLS
2833 // and is further constrained by |SSL_OP_NO_*|.
2834 uint16_t conf_max_version = 0;
2835
2836 // conf_min_version is the minimum acceptable version configured by
2837 // |SSL_set_min_proto_version|. Note this version is not normalized in DTLS
2838 // and is further constrained by |SSL_OP_NO_*|.
2839 uint16_t conf_min_version = 0;
2840
2841 X509_VERIFY_PARAM *param = nullptr;
2842
2843 // crypto
2844 UniquePtr<SSLCipherPreferenceList> cipher_list;
2845
2846 // This is used to hold the local certificate used (i.e. the server
2847 // certificate for a server or the client certificate for a client).
2848 UniquePtr<CERT> cert;
2849
2850 int (*verify_callback)(int ok,
2851 X509_STORE_CTX *ctx) =
2852 nullptr; // fail if callback returns 0
2853
2854 enum ssl_verify_result_t (*custom_verify_callback)(
2855 SSL *ssl, uint8_t *out_alert) = nullptr;
2856 // Server-only: psk_identity_hint is the identity hint to send in
2857 // PSK-based key exchanges.
2858 UniquePtr<char> psk_identity_hint;
2859
2860 unsigned (*psk_client_callback)(SSL *ssl, const char *hint, char *identity,
2861 unsigned max_identity_len, uint8_t *psk,
2862 unsigned max_psk_len) = nullptr;
2863 unsigned (*psk_server_callback)(SSL *ssl, const char *identity, uint8_t *psk,
2864 unsigned max_psk_len) = nullptr;
2865
2866 // for server side, keep the list of CA_dn we can use
2867 UniquePtr<STACK_OF(CRYPTO_BUFFER)> client_CA;
2868
2869 // cached_x509_client_CA is a cache of parsed versions of the elements of
2870 // |client_CA|.
2871 STACK_OF(X509_NAME) *cached_x509_client_CA = nullptr;
2872
2873 Array<uint16_t> supported_group_list; // our list
2874
2875 // The client's Channel ID private key.
2876 UniquePtr<EVP_PKEY> channel_id_private;
2877
2878 // For a client, this contains the list of supported protocols in wire
2879 // format.
2880 Array<uint8_t> alpn_client_proto_list;
2881
2882 // alps_configs contains the list of supported protocols to use with ALPS,
2883 // along with their corresponding ALPS values.
2884 GrowableArray<ALPSConfig> alps_configs;
2885
2886 // Contains a list of supported Token Binding key parameters.
2887 Array<uint8_t> token_binding_params;
2888
2889 // Contains the QUIC transport params that this endpoint will send.
2890 Array<uint8_t> quic_transport_params;
2891
2892 // Contains the context used to decide whether to accept early data in QUIC.
2893 Array<uint8_t> quic_early_data_context;
2894
2895 // verify_sigalgs, if not empty, is the set of signature algorithms
2896 // accepted from the peer in decreasing order of preference.
2897 Array<uint16_t> verify_sigalgs;
2898
2899 // srtp_profiles is the list of configured SRTP protection profiles for
2900 // DTLS-SRTP.
2901 UniquePtr<STACK_OF(SRTP_PROTECTION_PROFILE)> srtp_profiles;
2902
2903 // verify_mode is a bitmask of |SSL_VERIFY_*| values.
2904 uint8_t verify_mode = SSL_VERIFY_NONE;
2905
2906 // ech_grease_enabled controls whether ECH GREASE may be sent in the
2907 // ClientHello.
2908 bool ech_grease_enabled : 1;
2909
2910 // Enable signed certificate time stamps. Currently client only.
2911 bool signed_cert_timestamps_enabled : 1;
2912
2913 // ocsp_stapling_enabled is only used by client connections and indicates
2914 // whether OCSP stapling will be requested.
2915 bool ocsp_stapling_enabled : 1;
2916
2917 // channel_id_enabled is copied from the |SSL_CTX|. For a server, means that
2918 // we'll accept Channel IDs from clients. For a client, means that we'll
2919 // advertise support.
2920 bool channel_id_enabled : 1;
2921
2922 // If enforce_rsa_key_usage is true, the handshake will fail if the
2923 // keyUsage extension is present and incompatible with the TLS usage.
2924 // This field is not read until after certificate verification.
2925 bool enforce_rsa_key_usage : 1;
2926
2927 // retain_only_sha256_of_client_certs is true if we should compute the SHA256
2928 // hash of the peer's certificate and then discard it to save memory and
2929 // session space. Only effective on the server side.
2930 bool retain_only_sha256_of_client_certs : 1;
2931
2932 // handoff indicates that a server should stop after receiving the
2933 // ClientHello and pause the handshake in such a way that |SSL_get_error|
2934 // returns |SSL_ERROR_HANDOFF|. This is copied in |SSL_new| from the |SSL_CTX|
2935 // element of the same name and may be cleared if the handoff is declined.
2936 bool handoff : 1;
2937
2938 // shed_handshake_config indicates that the handshake config (this object!)
2939 // should be freed after the handshake completes.
2940 bool shed_handshake_config : 1;
2941
2942 // jdk11_workaround is whether to disable TLS 1.3 for JDK 11 clients, as a
2943 // workaround for https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8211806.
2944 bool jdk11_workaround : 1;
2945
2946 // QUIC drafts up to and including 32 used a different TLS extension
2947 // codepoint to convey QUIC's transport parameters.
2948 bool quic_use_legacy_codepoint : 1;
2949};
2950
2951// From RFC 8446, used in determining PSK modes.
2952#define SSL_PSK_DHE_KE 0x1
2953
2954// kMaxEarlyDataAccepted is the advertised number of plaintext bytes of early
2955// data that will be accepted. This value should be slightly below
2956// kMaxEarlyDataSkipped in tls_record.c, which is measured in ciphertext.
2957static const size_t kMaxEarlyDataAccepted = 14336;

3015// ssl_get_prev_session looks up the previous session based on |client_hello|.

3017// found. If the session could not be looked up synchronously, it returns
3018// |ssl_hs_pending_session| and should be called again. If a ticket could not be

3177// ssl_process_ticket processes a session ticket from the client. It returns
3178// one of:
3179// |ssl_ticket_aead_success|: |*out_session| is set to the parsed session and
3180// |*out_renew_ticket| is set to whether the ticket should be renewed.
3181// |ssl_ticket_aead_ignore_ticket|: |*out_renew_ticket| is set to whether a
3182// fresh ticket should be sent, but the given ticket cannot be used.
3183// |ssl_ticket_aead_retry|: the ticket could not be immediately decrypted.
3184// Retry later.
3185// |ssl_ticket_aead_error|: an error occured that is fatal to the connection.
3186enum ssl_ticket_aead_result_t ssl_process_ticket(
3187 SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs, UniquePtr<SSL_SESSION> *out_session,

3189 Span<const uint8_t> session_id);

3192// the signature. If the key is valid, it saves the Channel ID and returns true.
3193// Otherwise, it returns false.

3200
3201// tls1_channel_id_hash computes the hash to be signed by Channel ID and writes
3202// it to |out|, which must contain at least |EVP_MAX_MD_SIZE| bytes. It returns

3210
3211// ssl_do_channel_id_callback checks runs |hs->ssl->ctx->channel_id_cb| if
3212// necessary. It returns true on success and false on fatal error. Note that, on

3214// operation should be retried later.

3236
3237// Opaque C types.
3238//
3239// The following types are exported to C code as public typedefs, so they must
3240// be defined outside of the namespace.
3241
3242// ssl_method_st backs the public |SSL_METHOD| type. It is a compatibility
3243// structure to support the legacy version-locked methods.
3244struct ssl_method_st {
3245 // version, if non-zero, is the only protocol version acceptable to an
3246 // SSL_CTX initialized from this method.
3247 uint16_t version;
3248 // method is the underlying SSL_PROTOCOL_METHOD that initializes the
3249 // SSL_CTX.
3250 const bssl::SSL_PROTOCOL_METHOD *method;
3251 // x509_method contains pointers to functions that might deal with |X509|
3252 // compatibility, or might be a no-op, depending on the application.
3253 const bssl::SSL_X509_METHOD *x509_method;
3254};
3255
3256struct ssl_ctx_st {
3257 explicit ssl_ctx_st(const SSL_METHOD *ssl_method);
3258 ssl_ctx_st(const ssl_ctx_st &) = delete;
3259 ssl_ctx_st &operator=(const ssl_ctx_st &) = delete;
3260
3261 const bssl::SSL_PROTOCOL_METHOD *method = nullptr;
3262 const bssl::SSL_X509_METHOD *x509_method = nullptr;
3263
3264 // lock is used to protect various operations on this object.
3265 CRYPTO_MUTEX lock;
3266
3267 // conf_max_version is the maximum acceptable protocol version configured by
3268 // |SSL_CTX_set_max_proto_version|. Note this version is normalized in DTLS
3269 // and is further constrainted by |SSL_OP_NO_*|.
3270 uint16_t conf_max_version = 0;
3271
3272 // conf_min_version is the minimum acceptable protocol version configured by
3273 // |SSL_CTX_set_min_proto_version|. Note this version is normalized in DTLS
3274 // and is further constrainted by |SSL_OP_NO_*|.
3275 uint16_t conf_min_version = 0;
3276
3277 // quic_method is the method table corresponding to the QUIC hooks.
3278 const SSL_QUIC_METHOD *quic_method = nullptr;
3279
3280 bssl::UniquePtr<bssl::SSLCipherPreferenceList> cipher_list;
3281
3282 X509_STORE *cert_store = nullptr;
3283 LHASH_OF(SSL_SESSION) *sessions = nullptr;
3284 // Most session-ids that will be cached, default is
3285 // SSL_SESSION_CACHE_MAX_SIZE_DEFAULT. 0 is unlimited.
3286 unsigned long session_cache_size = SSL_SESSION_CACHE_MAX_SIZE_DEFAULT;
3287 SSL_SESSION *session_cache_head = nullptr;
3288 SSL_SESSION *session_cache_tail = nullptr;
3289
3290 // handshakes_since_cache_flush is the number of successful handshakes since
3291 // the last cache flush.
3292 int handshakes_since_cache_flush = 0;
3293
3294 // This can have one of 2 values, ored together,
3295 // SSL_SESS_CACHE_CLIENT,
3296 // SSL_SESS_CACHE_SERVER,
3297 // Default is SSL_SESSION_CACHE_SERVER, which means only
3298 // SSL_accept which cache SSL_SESSIONS.
3299 int session_cache_mode = SSL_SESS_CACHE_SERVER;
3300
3301 // session_timeout is the default lifetime for new sessions in TLS 1.2 and
3302 // earlier, in seconds.
3303 uint32_t session_timeout = SSL_DEFAULT_SESSION_TIMEOUT;
3304
3305 // session_psk_dhe_timeout is the default lifetime for new sessions in TLS
3306 // 1.3, in seconds.
3307 uint32_t session_psk_dhe_timeout = SSL_DEFAULT_SESSION_PSK_DHE_TIMEOUT;
3308
3309 // If this callback is not null, it will be called each time a session id is
3310 // added to the cache. If this function returns 1, it means that the
3311 // callback will do a SSL_SESSION_free() when it has finished using it.
3312 // Otherwise, on 0, it means the callback has finished with it. If
3313 // remove_session_cb is not null, it will be called when a session-id is
3314 // removed from the cache. After the call, OpenSSL will SSL_SESSION_free()
3315 // it.
3316 int (*new_session_cb)(SSL *ssl, SSL_SESSION *sess) = nullptr;
3317 void (*remove_session_cb)(SSL_CTX *ctx, SSL_SESSION *sess) = nullptr;
3318 SSL_SESSION *(*get_session_cb)(SSL *ssl, const uint8_t *data, int len,
3319 int *copy) = nullptr;
3320
3321 CRYPTO_refcount_t references = 1;
3322
3323 // if defined, these override the X509_verify_cert() calls
3324 int (*app_verify_callback)(X509_STORE_CTX *store_ctx, void *arg) = nullptr;
3325 void *app_verify_arg = nullptr;
3326
3327 ssl_verify_result_t (*custom_verify_callback)(SSL *ssl,
3328 uint8_t *out_alert) = nullptr;
3329
3330 // Default password callback.
3331 pem_password_cb *default_passwd_callback = nullptr;

3339

3343 CRYPTO_EX_DATA ex_data;

3349 // what we put in client cert requests
3350 bssl::UniquePtr<STACK_OF(CRYPTO_BUFFER)> client_CA;

3357 // Default values to use in SSL structures follow (these are copied by
3358 // SSL_new)

3362 // feature, but require callers opt into it.

3366 bssl::UniquePtr<bssl::CERT> cert;

3380 // select_certificate_cb is called before most ClientHello processing and

3384 nullptr;

3387 // has been made. It returns one to continue the handshake or zero to
3388 // abort.

3390
3391 // Controls whether to verify certificates when resuming connections. They
3392 // were already verified when the connection was first made, so the default is
3393 // false. For now, this is only respected on clients, not servers.
3394 bool reverify_on_resume = false;

3396 // Maximum amount of data to send in one fragment. actual record size can be
3397 // more than this due to padding and MAC overheads.
3398 uint16_t max_send_fragment = SSL3_RT_MAX_PLAIN_LENGTH;

3400 // TLS extensions servername callback
3401 int (*servername_callback)(SSL *, int *, void *) = nullptr;
3402 void *servername_arg = nullptr;

3404 // RFC 4507 session ticket keys. |ticket_key_current| may be NULL before the
3405 // first handshake and |ticket_key_prev| may be NULL at any time.
3406 // Automatically generated ticket keys are rotated as needed at handshake
3407 // time. Hence, all access must be synchronized through |lock|.
3408 bssl::UniquePtr<bssl::TicketKey> ticket_key_current;
3409 bssl::UniquePtr<bssl::TicketKey> ticket_key_prev;

3413 EVP_CIPHER_CTX *ectx, HMAC_CTX *hctx, int enc) = nullptr;

3416 // PSK-based key exchanges.
3417 bssl::UniquePtr<char> psk_identity_hint;

3420 unsigned max_identity_len, uint8_t *psk,
3421 unsigned max_psk_len) = nullptr;
3422 unsigned (*psk_server_callback)(SSL *ssl, const char *identity, uint8_t *psk,
3423 unsigned max_psk_len) = nullptr;
3424

3426 // Next protocol negotiation information
3427 // (for experimental NPN extension).
3428
3429 // For a server, this contains a callback function by which the set of
3430 // advertised protocols can be provided.
3431 int (*next_protos_advertised_cb)(SSL *ssl, const uint8_t **out,
3432 unsigned *out_len, void *arg) = nullptr;
3433 void *next_protos_advertised_cb_arg = nullptr;
3434 // For a client, this contains a callback function that selects the
3435 // next protocol from the list provided by the server.
3436 int (*next_proto_select_cb)(SSL *ssl, uint8_t **out, uint8_t *out_len,
3437 const uint8_t *in, unsigned in_len,
3438 void *arg) = nullptr;
3439 void *next_proto_select_cb_arg = nullptr;
3440
3441 // ALPN information
3442 // (we are in the process of transitioning from NPN to ALPN.)
3443
3444 // For a server, this contains a callback function that allows the
3445 // server to select the protocol for the connection.
3446 // out: on successful return, this must point to the raw protocol
3447 // name (without the length prefix).
3448 // outlen: on successful return, this contains the length of |*out|.
3449 // in: points to the client's list of supported protocols in
3450 // wire-format.
3451 // inlen: the length of |in|.
3452 int (*alpn_select_cb)(SSL *ssl, const uint8_t **out, uint8_t *out_len,
3453 const uint8_t *in, unsigned in_len,
3454 void *arg) = nullptr;
3455 void *alpn_select_cb_arg = nullptr;
3456
3457 // For a client, this contains the list of supported protocols in wire
3458 // format.
3459 bssl::Array<uint8_t> alpn_client_proto_list;
3460
3461 // SRTP profiles we are willing to do from RFC 5764
3462 bssl::UniquePtr<STACK_OF(SRTP_PROTECTION_PROFILE)> srtp_profiles;
3463
3464 // Defined compression algorithms for certificates.
3465 bssl::GrowableArray<bssl::CertCompressionAlg> cert_compression_algs;
3466
3467 // Supported group values inherited by SSL structure
3468 bssl::Array<uint16_t> supported_group_list;
3469
3470 // The client's Channel ID private key.
3471 bssl::UniquePtr<EVP_PKEY> channel_id_private;
3472
3473 // ech_server_config_list contains the server's list of ECHConfig values and
3474 // associated private keys. This list may be swapped out at any time, so all
3475 // access must be synchronized through |lock|.
3476 bssl::UniquePtr<SSL_ECH_SERVER_CONFIG_LIST> ech_server_config_list;
3477
3478 // keylog_callback, if not NULL, is the key logging callback. See
3479 // |SSL_CTX_set_keylog_callback|.
3480 void (*keylog_callback)(const SSL *ssl, const char *line) = nullptr;
3481
3482 // current_time_cb, if not NULL, is the function to use to get the current
3483 // time. It sets |*out_clock| to the current time. The |ssl| argument is
3484 // always NULL. See |SSL_CTX_set_current_time_cb|.
3485 void (*current_time_cb)(const SSL *ssl, struct timeval *out_clock) = nullptr;
3486
3487 // pool is used for all |CRYPTO_BUFFER|s in case we wish to share certificate
3488 // memory.
3489 CRYPTO_BUFFER_POOL *pool = nullptr;
3490
3491 // ticket_aead_method contains function pointers for opening and sealing
3492 // session tickets.
3493 const SSL_TICKET_AEAD_METHOD *ticket_aead_method = nullptr;
3494
3495 // legacy_ocsp_callback implements an OCSP-related callback for OpenSSL
3496 // compatibility.
3497 int (*legacy_ocsp_callback)(SSL *ssl, void *arg) = nullptr;
3498 void *legacy_ocsp_callback_arg = nullptr;
3499
3500 // verify_sigalgs, if not empty, is the set of signature algorithms
3501 // accepted from the peer in decreasing order of preference.
3502 bssl::Array<uint16_t> verify_sigalgs;
3503
3504 // retain_only_sha256_of_client_certs is true if we should compute the SHA256
3505 // hash of the peer's certificate and then discard it to save memory and
3506 // session space. Only effective on the server side.
3507 bool retain_only_sha256_of_client_certs : 1;
3508
3509 // quiet_shutdown is true if the connection should not send a close_notify on
3510 // shutdown.
3511 bool quiet_shutdown : 1;
3512
3513 // ocsp_stapling_enabled is only used by client connections and indicates
3514 // whether OCSP stapling will be requested.
3515 bool ocsp_stapling_enabled : 1;
3516
3517 // If true, a client will request certificate timestamps.
3518 bool signed_cert_timestamps_enabled : 1;
3519
3520 // channel_id_enabled is whether Channel ID is enabled. For a server, means
3521 // that we'll accept Channel IDs from clients. For a client, means that we'll
3522 // advertise support.
3523 bool channel_id_enabled : 1;
3524
3525 // grease_enabled is whether draft-davidben-tls-grease-01 is enabled.
3526 bool grease_enabled : 1;
3527
3528 // allow_unknown_alpn_protos is whether the client allows unsolicited ALPN
3529 // protocols from the peer.
3530 bool allow_unknown_alpn_protos : 1;
3531
3532 // false_start_allowed_without_alpn is whether False Start (if
3533 // |SSL_MODE_ENABLE_FALSE_START| is enabled) is allowed without ALPN.
3534 bool false_start_allowed_without_alpn : 1;
3535
3536 // handoff indicates that a server should stop after receiving the
3537 // ClientHello and pause the handshake in such a way that |SSL_get_error|
3538 // returns |SSL_ERROR_HANDOFF|.
3539 bool handoff : 1;
3540
3541 // If enable_early_data is true, early data can be sent and accepted.
3542 bool enable_early_data : 1;
3543
3544 private:
3545 ~ssl_ctx_st();
3546 friend void SSL_CTX_free(SSL_CTX *);
3547};

3549struct ssl_st {
3550 explicit ssl_st(SSL_CTX *ctx_arg);
3551 ssl_st(const ssl_st &) = delete;
3552 ssl_st &operator=(const ssl_st &) = delete;
3553 ~ssl_st();
3554
3555 // method is the method table corresponding to the current protocol (DTLS or
3556 // TLS).
3557 const bssl::SSL_PROTOCOL_METHOD *method = nullptr;
3558
3559 // config is a container for handshake configuration. Accesses to this field
3560 // should check for nullptr, since configuration may be shed after the
3561 // handshake completes. (If you have the |SSL_HANDSHAKE| object at hand, use
3562 // that instead, and skip the null check.)
3563 bssl::UniquePtr<bssl::SSL_CONFIG> config;
3564
3565 // version is the protocol version.
3566 uint16_t version = 0;
3567
3568 uint16_t max_send_fragment = 0;
3569
3570 // There are 2 BIO's even though they are normally both the same. This is so
3571 // data can be read and written to different handlers
3572
3573 bssl::UniquePtr<BIO> rbio; // used by SSL_read
3574 bssl::UniquePtr<BIO> wbio; // used by SSL_write
3575
3576 // do_handshake runs the handshake. On completion, it returns |ssl_hs_ok|.
3577 // Otherwise, it returns a value corresponding to what operation is needed to
3578 // progress.
3579 bssl::ssl_hs_wait_t (*do_handshake)(bssl::SSL_HANDSHAKE *hs) = nullptr;
3580
3581 bssl::SSL3_STATE *s3 = nullptr; // TLS variables
3582 bssl::DTLS1_STATE *d1 = nullptr; // DTLS variables
3583
3584 // callback that allows applications to peek at protocol messages
3585 void (*msg_callback)(int write_p, int version, int content_type,
3586 const void *buf, size_t len, SSL *ssl,
3587 void *arg) = nullptr;
3588 void *msg_callback_arg = nullptr;
3589
3590 // session info
3591
3592 // initial_timeout_duration_ms is the default DTLS timeout duration in
3593 // milliseconds. It's used to initialize the timer any time it's restarted.
3594 //
3595 // RFC 6347 states that implementations SHOULD use an initial timer value of 1
3596 // second.
3597 unsigned initial_timeout_duration_ms = 1000;
3598
3599 // session is the configured session to be offered by the client. This session
3600 // is immutable.
3601 bssl::UniquePtr<SSL_SESSION> session;
3602
3603 void (*info_callback)(const SSL *ssl, int type, int value) = nullptr;
3604
3605 bssl::UniquePtr<SSL_CTX> ctx;
3606
3607 // session_ctx is the |SSL_CTX| used for the session cache and related
3608 // settings.
3609 bssl::UniquePtr<SSL_CTX> session_ctx;
3610
3611 // extra application data
3612 CRYPTO_EX_DATA ex_data;
3613
3614 uint32_t options = 0; // protocol behaviour
3615 uint32_t mode = 0; // API behaviour
3616 uint32_t max_cert_list = 0;
3617 bssl::UniquePtr<char> hostname;
3618
3619 // quic_method is the method table corresponding to the QUIC hooks.
3620 const SSL_QUIC_METHOD *quic_method = nullptr;
3621
3622 // renegotiate_mode controls how peer renegotiation attempts are handled.
3623 ssl_renegotiate_mode_t renegotiate_mode = ssl_renegotiate_never;
3624
3625 // server is true iff the this SSL* is the server half. Note: before the SSL*
3626 // is initialized by either SSL_set_accept_state or SSL_set_connect_state,
3627 // the side is not determined. In this state, server is always false.
3628 bool server : 1;
3629
3630 // quiet_shutdown is true if the connection should not send a close_notify on
3631 // shutdown.
3632 bool quiet_shutdown : 1;
3633
3634 // If enable_early_data is true, early data can be sent and accepted.
3635 bool enable_early_data : 1;
3636};

3638struct ssl_session_st {
3639 explicit ssl_session_st(const bssl::SSL_X509_METHOD *method);
3640 ssl_session_st(const ssl_session_st &) = delete;
3641 ssl_session_st &operator=(const ssl_session_st &) = delete;
3642
3643 CRYPTO_refcount_t references = 1;
3644
3645 // ssl_version is the (D)TLS version that established the session.
3646 uint16_t ssl_version = 0;
3647
3648 // group_id is the ID of the ECDH group used to establish this session or zero
3649 // if not applicable or unknown.
3650 uint16_t group_id = 0;
3651
3652 // peer_signature_algorithm is the signature algorithm used to authenticate
3653 // the peer, or zero if not applicable or unknown.
3654 uint16_t peer_signature_algorithm = 0;
3655
3656 // secret, in TLS 1.2 and below, is the master secret associated with the
3657 // session. In TLS 1.3 and up, it is the resumption PSK for sessions handed to
3658 // the caller, but it stores the resumption secret when stored on |SSL|
3659 // objects.
3660 int secret_length = 0;
3661 uint8_t secret[SSL_MAX_MASTER_KEY_LENGTH] = {0};
3662
3663 // session_id - valid?
3664 unsigned session_id_length = 0;
3665 uint8_t session_id[SSL_MAX_SSL_SESSION_ID_LENGTH] = {0};
3666 // this is used to determine whether the session is being reused in
3667 // the appropriate context. It is up to the application to set this,
3668 // via SSL_new
3669 uint8_t sid_ctx_length = 0;
3670 uint8_t sid_ctx[SSL_MAX_SID_CTX_LENGTH] = {0};
3671
3672 bssl::UniquePtr<char> psk_identity;
3673
3674 // certs contains the certificate chain from the peer, starting with the leaf
3675 // certificate.
3676 bssl::UniquePtr<STACK_OF(CRYPTO_BUFFER)> certs;
3677
3678 const bssl::SSL_X509_METHOD *x509_method = nullptr;
3679
3680 // x509_peer is the peer's certificate.
3681 X509 *x509_peer = nullptr;
3682
3683 // x509_chain is the certificate chain sent by the peer. NOTE: for historical
3684 // reasons, when a client (so the peer is a server), the chain includes
3685 // |peer|, but when a server it does not.
3686 STACK_OF(X509) *x509_chain = nullptr;
3687
3688 // x509_chain_without_leaf is a lazily constructed copy of |x509_chain| that
3689 // omits the leaf certificate. This exists because OpenSSL, historically,
3690 // didn't include the leaf certificate in the chain for a server, but did for
3691 // a client. The |x509_chain| always includes it and, if an API call requires
3692 // a chain without, it is stored here.
3693 STACK_OF(X509) *x509_chain_without_leaf = nullptr;
3694
3695 // verify_result is the result of certificate verification in the case of
3696 // non-fatal certificate errors.
3697 long verify_result = X509_V_ERR_INVALID_CALL;
3698
3699 // timeout is the lifetime of the session in seconds, measured from |time|.
3700 // This is renewable up to |auth_timeout|.
3701 uint32_t timeout = SSL_DEFAULT_SESSION_TIMEOUT;
3702
3703 // auth_timeout is the non-renewable lifetime of the session in seconds,
3704 // measured from |time|.
3705 uint32_t auth_timeout = SSL_DEFAULT_SESSION_TIMEOUT;
3706
3707 // time is the time the session was issued, measured in seconds from the UNIX
3708 // epoch.
3709 uint64_t time = 0;
3710
3711 const SSL_CIPHER *cipher = nullptr;
3712
3713 CRYPTO_EX_DATA ex_data; // application specific data
3714
3715 // These are used to make removal of session-ids more efficient and to
3716 // implement a maximum cache size.
3717 SSL_SESSION *prev = nullptr, *next = nullptr;
3718
3719 bssl::Array<uint8_t> ticket;
3720
3721 bssl::UniquePtr<CRYPTO_BUFFER> signed_cert_timestamp_list;
3722
3723 // The OCSP response that came with the session.
3724 bssl::UniquePtr<CRYPTO_BUFFER> ocsp_response;
3725
3726 // peer_sha256 contains the SHA-256 hash of the peer's certificate if
3727 // |peer_sha256_valid| is true.
3728 uint8_t peer_sha256[SHA256_DIGEST_LENGTH] = {0};
3729
3730 // original_handshake_hash contains the handshake hash (either SHA-1+MD5 or
3731 // SHA-2, depending on TLS version) for the original, full handshake that
3732 // created a session. This is used by Channel IDs during resumption.
3733 uint8_t original_handshake_hash[EVP_MAX_MD_SIZE] = {0};
3734 uint8_t original_handshake_hash_len = 0;
3735
3736 uint32_t ticket_lifetime_hint = 0; // Session lifetime hint in seconds
3737
3738 uint32_t ticket_age_add = 0;
3739
3740 // ticket_max_early_data is the maximum amount of data allowed to be sent as
3741 // early data. If zero, 0-RTT is disallowed.
3742 uint32_t ticket_max_early_data = 0;
3743
3744 // early_alpn is the ALPN protocol from the initial handshake. This is only
3745 // stored for TLS 1.3 and above in order to enforce ALPN matching for 0-RTT
3746 // resumptions. For the current connection's ALPN protocol, see
3747 // |alpn_selected| on |SSL3_STATE|.
3748 bssl::Array<uint8_t> early_alpn;
3749
3750 // local_application_settings, if |has_application_settings| is true, is the
3751 // local ALPS value for this connection.
3752 bssl::Array<uint8_t> local_application_settings;
3753
3754 // peer_application_settings, if |has_application_settings| is true, is the
3755 // peer ALPS value for this connection.
3756 bssl::Array<uint8_t> peer_application_settings;
3757
3758 // extended_master_secret is whether the master secret in this session was
3759 // generated using EMS and thus isn't vulnerable to the Triple Handshake
3760 // attack.
3761 bool extended_master_secret : 1;
3762
3763 // peer_sha256_valid is whether |peer_sha256| is valid.
3764 bool peer_sha256_valid : 1; // Non-zero if peer_sha256 is valid
3765
3766 // not_resumable is used to indicate that session resumption is disallowed.
3767 bool not_resumable : 1;
3768
3769 // ticket_age_add_valid is whether |ticket_age_add| is valid.
3770 bool ticket_age_add_valid : 1;
3771
3772 // is_server is whether this session was created by a server.
3773 bool is_server : 1;
3774
3775 // is_quic indicates whether this session was created using QUIC.
3776 bool is_quic : 1;
3777
3778 // has_application_settings indicates whether ALPS was negotiated in this
3779 // session.
3780 bool has_application_settings : 1;
3781
3782 // quic_early_data_context is used to determine whether early data must be
3783 // rejected when performing a QUIC handshake.
3784 bssl::Array<uint8_t> quic_early_data_context;
3785
3786 private:
3787 ~ssl_session_st();
3788 friend void SSL_SESSION_free(SSL_SESSION *);
3789};
3790
3791struct ssl_ech_server_config_list_st {
3792 ssl_ech_server_config_list_st() = default;
3793 ssl_ech_server_config_list_st(const ssl_ech_server_config_list_st &) = delete;
3794 ssl_ech_server_config_list_st &operator=(
3795 const ssl_ech_server_config_list_st &) = delete;
3796
3797 bssl::GrowableArray<bssl::UniquePtr<bssl::ECHServerConfig>> configs;
3798 CRYPTO_refcount_t references = 1;
3799
3800 private:
3801 ~ssl_ech_server_config_list_st() = default;
3802 friend void SSL_ECH_SERVER_CONFIG_LIST_free(SSL_ECH_SERVER_CONFIG_LIST *);
3803};
